Project Title: Renovate the O'Connell Library; including the rug, floor, tables and a new air conditioner
Project Description: This is needed because the library is a very active place and the furniture is worn out.
Project Status: This project made it to the ballot, but didn't receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: New furniture for the O'Connell Library
Project Description: The library needs new furniture and maybe a play area for the kids like the main library on Broadway Street. There are not many programs and places for the kids to play when we compare to the areas in Cambridgeport and Inman Square, etc...
Project Status: This project made it to the ballot, but didn't receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Renovate the Cambridge Public Library branches, especially the Central Square branch
Project Description: The Main Library is great, but many branches are dark and old, especially the Central Square branch.  I'd like to take my kids there more often, but it's dark and stinky and I don't always feel safe and comfortable there.
Project Status: Renovations for the O'Connell Library branch made it to the ballot, but didn't receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Main Library improvements
Project Description: 1. Free parking.  2. Paid parking to be longer than 2 hours (not enough for meetings).  3. Buses to library stop to be free.  4. Regular copying machine.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not move this idea forward because only the copier was eligible for capital funds, and the Library director said that the copiers were purposely removed in favor of scanners.

Project Title: Improvements to all libraries
Project Description: More computers.  Tax forms.  Tool check out.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To add new furniture and other improvements to neighborhood library
Project Description: The library on the corner of Sixth and Thorndike Street is very active and gets a lot of use. The library is an important part of our neighborhood.
Project Status: This project made it to the ballot, but didn't receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Add tools to the items eligible for checkout from the library
Project Description:
Similar to renting books, dvd's, or e-readers from the library, it would be helpful to residents to be able to rent common tools that aren't necessary to own but are needed on occasion for projects at their house or apartment. Similar to books, you may only need use of it for a short time, so it would eliminate unnecessary expense or waste if it could be shared among the community.

(I'm not totally sure if this qualifies as a capital expense, but I think the initial addition of these items would be?)
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not move this idea forward because it would require operating funds.

Project Title: Longer weekend hours at the library
Project Description: Weekends are when most people want to use the library, but the hours tend to be shorter then. It cost something like $100 million, I heard, to reconstruct this library. The wonderful facility should get a lot more use than it does. But the biggest obstacle is that it just isn't open at the times that people want to use it.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds. This idea was shared with the Library Director.

Project Title: Amphitheater at the library park for plays, music and movies
Project Description: It would build a better community to have outdoor cultural activities that everyone could enjoy.
Project Status: This idea made it to the ballot (location was changed to Danehy Park), but didn't get enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: "Daylighting" the Main Library stairwell
Project Description: Portions of the library are not accessible via the stairwell--perhaps a security issue or a design/programing slip--but it has been WONDERFUL to be able to use the stairs to get to the auditorium while the elevators have been under repair (and the world hasn't come to an end).  The new LEED requirements include credit for creating visible, inviting, usable stairs, and to support the City's commitment to green building, it would be great to retrofit the stairs to be usable at all times to reach ALL public portions of the building.
Project Status: Not feasible - stairwell is locked due to safety concerns.

Project Title: Library Branch near Boardman Street. Or Bookmobile.
Project Description: More Branch or Bookmobile Cambridge Public Library services would provide better access to library services.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds.

Project Title: To share gaming spaces of cultural variety.
Project Description: It can promote a sense of community, and healthy learning and cultural environment. Make spaces for activities such as chess, volleyball, bocce, etc.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Book houses with multilingual first books for children. Near schools and tot lots.
Project Description: Having your own books is important to beginning readers.  Providing free multilingual books in book houses on Cambridge streets near schools would provide first books for young readers who may be learning English and speaking other languages at home.  Suggest working with the Cambridge community engagement team which has a program to encourage parents reading to children at home.  For examples of book houses check existing "take a book/leave a book houses" on streets in Somerville and Boston - and build them lower so children can reach in and get a book.
Project Status: This idea was split into two projects on the ballot. The first project, which won funding, was to purchase 300+ bilingual books for Cambridge children learning English through the Agenda for Children's Literacy Initiative.  The second, which did not receive enough votes to win funding, would have set up little free libraries/book houses around the city.

Project Title: A makerspace at the Cambridge Public Library
Project Description: it's a way of engaging young people (especially) in Cambridge with the technology that is so important in our city and our world.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not move this idea forward, because the Library Director said that they are already thinking about creating a makerspace.

Project Title: Create a makerspace at the Cambridge Public Library
Project Description:
We at the precipice of a technological revolution. In the words of Neil Gershenfeld, once upon a time computers were large bulky machines that took up an entire room and were operated by people with specialized training. This is quite similar to fabrication and manufacturing technology today: for the most part the things we use are created by large specialized machines by people with specialized knowledge. 

Tools for digital fabrication such as 3D printers and CNC machines mark a turning point in the evolution of how we make things. Democratizing access to these relatively expensive tools perhaps can inspire a generation and reinforce the cultural importance of the library (as has been done in other cities).
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not move this idea forward, because the Library Director said that they are already thinking about creating a makerspace.

Project Title: To have more career resources at libraries.
Project Description: To help connect others with jobs.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds. Idea was shared with the Department of Human Service Programs.

Project Title: A well-equipped training kitchen
Project Description: It will help people who want to be promoted from kitchen helper to chef or unemployed people who need job-like experience
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.
Idea Submitter: Rebecca Pomerantz and students from the Citizenship class at CLC

Project Title: Financial resource center
Project Description: Many people don't know enough about their own finances
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds. The Community Development Department offers similar programs.

Project Title: Repair the Jackson Gardens and add more floor
Project Description: Cambridge is more safe and people are struggling for a place to live.
Project Status: Projects in Cambridge Housing Authority properties were not eligible.

Project Title: To build sleeping pods on public land overnight throught Cambridge.
Project Description: It would be a safe, warm place to sleep for those without homes.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not move this idea forward, because it would require operating funds for security, social services, maintenance, etc.

Project Title: Partner with developer to create mixed-income housing for those committed to giving back to the city
Project Description:
The Cambridge housing market has become unreasonably unaffordable with successful buyers paying in cash and at well-over the asking price. This is pushing out would-be buyers who could afford to pay decent-sized mortgages and income taxes to help the city but can't compete with those buyers or pay a 20% downpayment of $100,000 or more. Low-income housing is also a problem.

The city should partner and provide incentives to a private developer who sets aside a percentage of units for not only low-income housing units but middle-income units as well. In return, in order to qualify for such units, potential buyers shall sign a contract committing to give back to the city of Cambridge through a variety of means including civic engagement and volunteerism.
Project Status: This idea is not eligible for PB funds (private developers not eligible to receive PB funds), plus it's not a one-time expenditure.

Project Title: A drop-in day center for people who are homeless
Project Description: This center would have services, wifi, lockers, phones, and activities that focus on helping people get permanent shelter. It should be located somewhere near Central Square.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds. Idea was shared with the Department of Human Service Programs.

Project Title: More trees
Project Status: This project won funding! 100 new trees will be planted in FY16 (in addition to the trees Public Works was already planning to plant).

Project Title: Converting infrastructure of Foundry Building into Full Service Homeless Shelter,etc.
Project Description: My project idea is to convert the infrastructure of the Foundry Building, at  101 Rogers Street in Cambridge Massachusetts, into shelter spaces and units, to address homelessness, and for the providing of supportive affordable housing services, etc. My project idea begins with the hiring of a Nonprofit Consultant, that specializes in Homelessness/Housing and Urban Development (HUD) issues and priorities, for Capacity Building, and to work diligently and collaboratively, with the Cambridge Continuum of Care (CoC),its Working Group on Homelessness, Alliance of Cambridge Tenants (ACT), and other community entities that serve our local poor populations, based on those with the greatest needs, such as the homeless, and other low income subgroups.
Project Status: Not eligible - too expensive and would require operating funds. City Council is currently reviewing options for future uses of the building.

Project Title: To begin to implement a municipal broadband system
Project Description: This begins to address the digital divide in Cambridge. MANY of those in public and low income housing do not have internet access. This is one way to address the achievement gap - students without internet access at home are already at an extreme disadvantage.
Project Status: A scaled back public Wi-Fi project won funding.

Project Title: City-wide free wifi
Project Description: If too expensive, start with lower-income areas, especially "projects"
Project Status: A scaled back public Wi-Fi project won funding.

Project Title: Free wifi for all public housing, non-profit, and elderly (affordable) properties in Cambridge
Project Description: This should be located at all affordable housing (low and moderate income) buildings/properties in Cambridge (CHA and others). Free wifi will help bridge the "digital divide" in a city where we have Google, Microsoft, MIT, Harvard, etc.
Project Status: A scaled back public Wi-Fi project won funding.

Project Title: Free wifi for work, school, etc. around City/public housing
Project Status: A scaled back public Wi-Fi project won funding.

Project Title: Expand free, usable wifi in Cambridge squares and in public housing, starting with newtowne court an
Project Description: Important to level the playing field between the haves and have nots in the digital age
Project Status: A scaled back public Wi-Fi project won funding.

Project Title: An App - Identify Accessible entrances and routes to buildings, facilities, throughout the City
Project Description: Accessible entrances to facilities are not always straightforward to find.  For example, an entrance at an address may have stairs and a person may need to hunt for the accessible entrance, which may be on an entirely different street and hard to locate. Persons with disabilities often making phone calls, e-mails, and special arrangements to get in the accessible entrance to facilities. To enhance equal opportunity to attend events, shop at stores, participate in community life, a Citywide App that identifies the accessible entrance would be of great benefit.  This would not only benefit persons with disabilities, but parents with small children and strollers, cyclists, and others preferring barrier free entry.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: A facility where families can receive information on money matters.
Project Description: I have not seen a facility where families can learn about budgeting, have job counseling, and receive information pertaining to money. This is very important and many families lack the knowledge.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds. The Community Development Department offers similar programs.

Project Title: Put Fire Dept Permit Application Process On Line
Project Description: The sale of a property in MA requires a Fire Dept inspection of smoke and CO detectors. To schedule and pay for an inspection appointment in Cambridge, one must physically go to the 2nd floor of the Main Fire Dept building at the intersection of Broadway/Cambridge/Quincy to complete an application and provide a check or cash. The hours available to do this are 8-10am and 2-3pm weekdays. The building is not pedestrian-accessible without walking through a planting bed or along the edge of the roadway. Inspection scheduling and payment could be processed on line as moving van permits are. A signature is required on the application, but that could be handled through on-line registry or at the time of the inspection at the property.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Digitize Property Files
Project Description: Make publicly available property information accessible on-line. Registry of Deeds information and Assessor reports are already available on line, but Inspectional Services records, Historical Commission information, and Fire Department records for specific addresses are not available on line. Making the information more easily accessible would benefit property owners, purchasers, renters, and would reduce traffic to each department.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To make public and collaborative art walls, structures, graffiti, etc.
Project Description: It can build a sense of community, make outlet for creative expression.
Project Status: Budget Delegates contacted 3 organizations in different parts of Cambridge and some community artists, but there was no response to this project idea.

Project Title: To build an app to show inter-generational volunteer gaps
Project Description: It can help share information to the community and also make it be language accessible to the city.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Study the tax paying relationships between other city/institutions.
Project Description: It can be used as a city website that is accessible to the public in regard to existing public project locations. It can help motivate institutions to contribute to ideas, as well as showing transparency and fairness in city/nonprofit institutions.
Project Status: Not eligible - not a capital project.

Project Title: More Equipment For The Youth Centers
Project Description: Basketball have taken over the space in the gyms and only people that play basketball show up to the youth center and not enough other types of people. The goal is to have as many students to come by the youth centers to play the other sports that they want to play. The kind of equirments that's need are scoccer goals, dodge balls,  hockey sticks, and cones.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: A weekend-only youth center (could be located anywhere in the city)
Project Description: All youth centers are open Monday-Friday.  If they were open on a weekend it would encourage more kids to come rather than doing something they shouldn't be doing.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds. Idea was shared with the Department of Human Service Programs.

Project Title: Mural at Russell Field
Project Description: The mural can show the community of Cambridge
Project Status: This idea made it to the ballot, but didn't get enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Community and citywide "recycling" options
Project Description: Books, eyeglasses, cell phones, small electrical and electronic, etc. items to be gathered on garbage days and taken to citywide recycling location, which would eventually distribute to charity.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds.

Project Title: More community availability of rooms - free! - in public housing and buildings
Project Status: Budget Delegates proposed a project to replace the roof at Centro Latino, which had room for community groups to meet, but the project cost exceeded $500,000.

Project Title: Indoor public meeting space.
Project Description: It can be a space to gather in bad weather.
Project Status: Budget Delegates proposed a project to replace the roof at Centro Latino, which had room for community groups to meet, but the project cost exceeded $500,000.

Project Title: An indoor open community space for groups and organizations to meet
Project Description: His is needed because there are not enough free, open community, indoor spaces for children 0-5, especially during normal nap times
Project Status: Budget Delegates proposed a project to replace the roof at Centro Latino, which had room for community groups to meet, but the project cost exceeded $500,000.

Project Title: Practice rooms in public housing and buildings
Project Status: Budget Delegates proposed a project to replace the roof at Centro Latino, which had room for community groups to meet, but the project cost exceeded $500,000.

Project Title: Use public rooms for art displays, performances, etc.
Project Description: (Not just CMAC.)
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds. Idea was shared with the Cambridge Arts Council.

Project Title: More block parties possible; no mandatory police presentations.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds.

Project Title: More events like community repair days
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds.

Project Title: Replacement of "matched" trees that get sick with the same species
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: City to facilitate occasional neighborhood discussions on any topics desired at the time.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds. Community Development Department  facilitates these types of meetings.

Project Title: City public meetings to take place at staggered times and days, so more can attend at least some.
Project Description: Children to be accommodated.  Translation to be arranged.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds.

Project Title: Cambridge Street
Project Description: There are a lot of store front vacancies, and we need more culture and arts centers. Partner with MIT, hire a curator, and make a space for contemporary art.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds. Idea was shared with the Cambridge Arts Council.

Project Title: Fund a new holiday lighting program relocating the twinkle lights around Civil War monument
Project Description: It will allow Cambridge's most important monument to be displayed with energy efficient lighting without extraneous distractions.  Would the Lincoln Memorial (DC) be surrounded by twinkle lights?  The project can be done in conjunction with the Cambridge Common project currently under construction.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Exterior lighting of City Hall with energy-efficient fixtures that highlight the architecture
Project Description: Highlight City Hall on the 125th anniversary of its construction.  Draw attention to its important architectural features.  Save energy by replacing existing lighting with new low energy lighting.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Holiday "light curtains" in Harvard Square
Project Description: Supports local holiday shopping.  Today, we have 4 beautiful holiday light curtains that hang over the streets in Harvard Square.  It would really light up the Square if we had 4 more.  I understand they cost between $5-10K each.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Create a winter or holiday light installment on the Fresh Pond Golf Course
Project Description: There are some concerns that the Golf Course is not universally usable by the people of Cambridge. Many other cities host "winter wonderlands" of decorated trees and light shows. Adding this to the golf course while it is closed in winter would be a nice attraction and usable by lots of people.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Electronic billboard sign in front of City Hall
Project Description: To inform residents of upcoming events and meetings
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Digital video sign
Project Description: Help promote more events and allow for special or emergency messages to be promoted on the sign. Do this at other locations as well
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Community bulletin boards.
Project Description: These should be local, but also include City notices (upcoming events, festivals, social services, elections, etc.) in multiple languages.
Project Status: Public Works already has plans to do this and will work with neighborhoods and businesses on locations and designs.

Project Title: Fund summertime activities in Vellucci Plaza- like the piano vents a year or so ago
Project Description: Energize the square and plaza with activity
Project Status: Budget Delegates consulted with Cambridge Arts Council, but this idea would involve operating funds and is therefore not eligible.

Project Title: More laptops for the Community Learning Center
Project Description: There are not enough computers for students to use at the CLC.
Project Status: This project won funding!

Project Title: Cookery School For Kids and Families
Project Description:
Here at the Cambridge Cookery School families can strengthen their bonds over cooking lessons from the top local chefs. Kids will strengthen their knowledge of math and science through cooking--like hiding cauliflower in mashed potatoes! 

Family, food, and education, three things that are indispensable for a strong community.
Project Status: Not eligible - not public property.

Project Title: More "recycling" options, not just books.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: A recording (& dance?) studio/music space
Project Description: primarily for younger people in the former N.C. - J.P. CHA Health Clinic at Jefferson Park/Jackson Place. Young people need opportunities to be creative and enjoy creative expressions while also developing skills that will be useful for a lifetime.  Younger people at Jefferson Park (and nearby areas) don't really have easy access to this kind of enjoyable and creative activity in the immediate neighborhood.
Project Status: Projects in Cambridge Housing Authority properties were not eligible. Budget Delegates proposed a project to replace the roof at Centro Latino, which had room for community groups to meet, but the project cost exceeded $500,000.

Project Title: Public & cultural information (circular) kiosk in front of the post office in Central Square
Project Description: The kiosk should be located on the brick sidewalk area near Hubway on Mass Ave - Parisian style!  The kiosk would increase sharing of community, public/civic, and cultural information.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project; operating costs would have exceeded capital costs.

Project Title: To restore the "Gift of wind" kinetic sculpture at Porter T Station
Project Description: This is one of Cambridge's most notable landmarks and an art icon of the city for decades.  Sadly, it had faded to a chalky pink and streaked with rust, instead of its original vibrant red.  So much has been invested in Porter Square by the MBTA to upgraded the exterior of the station and pedestrian access along with the cities investment into the street scape at Porter Square shopping center, that the sculpture's neglect stands out even more in contrast.
Project Status: Not eligible - MBTA property.

Project Title: Commission up to $150,000 in public art for Cambridge artists
Project Description: There is so little $ for public art
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds. Idea was shared with the Cambridge Arts Council.

Project Title: A new flag to replace the shredded one on the front of the Cambridgeport School
Project Description: Apparently there is not enough $ to replace or mend the American flag on the school....come by,and take a look at the condition of the flag
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Fund mobile camera for the city manager, the council and CDD staff to see if the meet more often wit
Project Description: We need to hold these elected officials, the city manager and community development personnel accountable.....it is time they meet with the community, not just the developers
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Community Photo Booth
Project Description: Through photographs of community members we can capture the images and stories of the people who live and walk-through this unique city. Web need to gather the on-going history and social movement of Cambridge.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. The operating cost may have exceeded the capital cost of the project.

Project Title: Get Gordon Ramsey to teach the school lunch cooks
Project Description: This is needed because all Cambridge Public School lunches are nasty and we need to improve them.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds.

Project Title: Making school lunch better by getting a special class for the cooks.
Project Description: People are not eating lunch because it's bad
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds.

Project Title: To make the CPS school lunch better
Project Description: By making the pizza better on Fridays by getting special classes for the cooks. This is needed because people don't eat lunch because the food is bad.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds.

Project Title: To purchase a new health curriculum for the Amigos Middle School
Project Description: Needed because the current health curriculum at the Amigos Middle School is outdated and stereotypical, it feeds into extreme stereotypes of girls, specific races and age
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds.

Project Title: Do not spend the $500,000. Reduce taxes at next collection by equal amount.
Project Description: Basic idea of Thomas Paine. As the ethical default, government must only do as little as possible.
Project Status: Not a capital project.

Project Title: Citizen parks within existing park and open spaces.
Project Description: it can be a citizen led gardening, beautification. Also, better utilization of scarce resources
Project Status: Two community garden projects made it to the ballot, but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: An outdoor performance venue for theater, music etc. in Sennot Park or Danehy
Project Description: Cambridge needs more outdoor performance space for people to collectively experience music, theater and are.  I would suggest building an outdoor performance space (like harbor lights or like the stage in Davis Square behind the T)
Project Status: This idea made it to the ballot (amphitheater in Danehy Park), but didn't get enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: A Better Use for this Neglected Public Space
Project Description: Public art? A garden? A market space? Anything would be better than the current, empty nothingness.
Project Status: The City plans to reconstruct this plaza as part of the ongoing sewer separation project there.

Project Title: Add money for adult education
Project Description: Many immigrants' English is limited. They need more opportunities to study and improve their life.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds.

Project Title: A specific area for the street performers
Project Description: Some performers are really skilled but they don't have a good place to show their talent.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Provide school supplies for Peabody Parks School
Project Description: This is needed to help people learn better and to make other people happy. Also to get better lunches.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. Lunches not eligible for capital funds.

Project Title: Mapping buildings for sale for creating community spaces ground level with housing
Project Description: There are no longer community gathering spaces - for meetings, events, socializing across age, neighborhood and background. Lyndell's, Kelly/river st etc. cant the city take these buildings and open them to community uses.
Project Status: Projects in Cambridge Housing Authority property were not eligible. Budget Delegates proposed a project to replace the roof at Centro Latino, which had room for community groups to meet, but the project cost exceeded $500,000.

Project Title: Offer more classes for Senior Citizens
Project Description: To help senior citizens
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds. Idea was shared with Department of Human Service Programs.

Project Title: Fix the Senior Center bathrooms
Project Description: They are breeding grounds for infection and they smell. Update the towel dispensers, faucets, hand sanitizers, etc.  Seniors have paid the longest into the "system"
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Neighborhood. Participation. Simple.
Project Description:
Respect, accountability, fairness, and transparency: What do you know about your Cambridge neighbors' concerns? And when a concern is specified, how do you know if it's changing, getting better, remaining the same, or getting worse? If we can see how the tension of problems and solutions impacts us, couldn't we make better budgeting decisions? I think so. After all, it's your money :)

Relevant details: It's on the Web. Use it from your laptop, a PC at the library or senior center, or an app on your smartphone. Fast, restrained, and elegant. Is that what you want?
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Community garden at Donnelly Field
Project Description: The park gets a lot of sun and would be a great place for a community garden. Kids could get involved with the garden through City Sprouts or other organizations.
Project Status: Two community garden projects made it to the ballot, but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Build garden of peace with individual stones.
Project Description: it keeps memories alive, use as a reflection space, and educate community with solidarity.
Project Status: This project made it to the ballot, but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: To have small community gardens.
Project Description: the unused land could be a place for growth, connection to the ecosystem, and supply land for gardeners.
Project Status: Two community garden projects made it to the ballot, but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Public garden
Project Description: the unused land could be used as a garden.
Project Status: Two community garden projects made it to the ballot, but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Swing Set in Newtowne Court
Project Status: Cambridge Housing Authority properties are not eligible.

Project Title: Build roof gardens.
Project Description: it can help improve the community.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. They were also unsure as to whether rooftop gardens could be publicly accessible.

Project Title: North Cambridge Community Garden
Project Description: A community garden in the rectangular grass, either to the right or the left whichever gets more sun, where Harvey Street meets Russell Field.
Project Status: This project made it to the ballot, but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Raised garden beds around the periphery of Raymond Park; upgrade of garden at Walden St. entrance
Project Description: The circular garden at the Walden Street entrance to Raymond Park currently lies pretty fallow.  Perhaps it could become a community garden plot?  Raised garden beds along the park fencing might expand community gardening opportunities.  Perhaps garden plots could be adopted by neighborhood groups or after-school or nursery programs if individuals on community garden wait lists aren't available to garden.
Project Status: Two community garden projects (including improving the community garden in Raymond Park) made it to the ballot, but did not receive enough votes to win funding. A separate project for planting materials for residents and raised beds for food plants also made it to the ballot, but did not win funding.

Project Title: Consider open space - pocket parks, community gardens, etc., whereever there is space
Project Status: Two community garden projects made it to the ballot, but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Create school garden
Project Description: There is currently no garden. It needs to be developed and maintained.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Whittemore Avenue Community Garden
Project Description: Purchase the land and reestablish the community garden at this location.
Project Status: Not possible to purchase the land in the suggested location. Two community garden projects made it to the ballot, but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Improve the community garden at Pemberton
Project Status: Two community garden projects made it to the ballot, but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Rain gardens/bioswales/permeable paving on Mass Ave medians.
Project Description: The city could install bioswales, permeable paving and rain gardens on the median strips of Massachusetts Avenue for stormwater management in an age of climatic change. This is being done in Chicago, Portland, NYC ... It would also beautify the street and perhaps decrease jaywalking.
Project Status: Not eligible - the operating cost would exceed the capital cost. Budget Delegates consulted with a City engineer, who advised that there is not enough space on medians for rain gardens. There are planned or constructed rain gardens on Western Avenue, Huron Avenue, Whittemore Avenue, and Fawcett Street, some of which include permeable paving.

Project Title: install more solar panels on the Daniel F. Burns apartments
Project Description: I think the current system ther is 47Kw, but according to the cambridge solar mapping this huge roof could economically accomodate a 191 Kw system  This investment will make money for the city over time and helpf us reduce our carbon emissions
Project Status: Not eligible - not public property.

Project Title: Install solar panels and store battery.
Project Description: it can help save money, reduce pollution. Educate children about conservation.
Project Status: Budget Delegates recommended a project to install solar panels on the Peabody School for the ballot, but project cost exceeded $500,000.

Project Title: Community solar (help with start-up if needed) for public buildings.
Project Status: Budget Delegates recommended a project to install solar panels on the Peabody School for the ballot, but project cost exceeded $500,000.

Project Title: Installation of photovoltaic panels for electricity production on city owned buildings
Project Description: It would drive down city electricity costs enhancing available discretionary funds, for years to come.  It will also help the environment by advancing the replacement of fossil fueled energy sources.
Project Status: The Water Department, City Hall Annex, King Open School, and Kennedy Longfellow School will have PV panels. Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: More tools to check out at recycling.
Project Status: This is an ongoing growing Public Works program. In FY16, curbside organics collection will expand to the entire Monday collection route.

Project Title: District geothermal
Project Description: Many property owners in Cambridge cannot install geothermal heat pumps because of lack of space on their property to drill geothermal loops underground. The city could provide geothermal loops under the streets however, and allow property owners to connect to the loops for a monthly fee. This benefits the city by reducing our collective carbon emissions towards our net zero goals and making the city a more desirable place for people who want to live green. Also the revenues from the connection fees can offset the costs of drilling and maintaining these loops, making it a revenue neutral proposition.
Project Status: Not eligible - too expensive.

Project Title: Energy efficiency upgrades in public schools
Project Description: Cambridge is a great proponent of energy efficiency (LED streetlights, Cambridge Energy Alliance). Let's take it a step further and improve the energy use of the city's public schools, such as the Graham and Parks School. It benefits the school and tax payers financially as well as the students and other occupants who will experience improved comfort. It also increases resiliency and reliability during shortages and of course makes a positive impact on the environment.
Project Status: This is an ongoing project between Public Works and the Schools.

Project Title: Filter on all Buildings
Project Description: This is needed because the soot that comes out of the buildings is awful.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Protect space for future neighborhood sustainability.
Project Description: It can help retain and improve the community.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: What do fire trucks, professional ambulances, tow trucks, and city specialty trucks have in common?
Project Description:
What do our fire trucks, professional ambulances, police project tow trucks, and giant utility trucks in Cambridge all have in common?  They pump out choking blue-black exhaust that the regular FedEx and UPS delivery trucks are not allowed to do.  Most air pollution in Cambridge is produced by the city. Make all city trucks, and city contracted trucks, obey the same emission rules as the regular public.
Why do ambulances drive & race madly, but once at the address, the drivers stay seated checking cell phones & putting on rubber gloves 1-finger at a time and SLOWLY open their doors & step out. There is no sense of urgency. Because they are not really used as 1st responders, they should drive to the address obeying the speed limit & with no sirens.
Last, all of these trucks when not on a call should obey the 5 minute engine idle law. People who live near take-out restaurants are being choked.
Project Status: Not a capital project. All purchases go through Community Development Department's Green Fleet Committee.

Project Title: Study global warming impact.
Project Description: it can help teach and educate people in the community so we have a safe environmental future.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds. Ongoing Climate Change Vulnerability Assessment will be published this spring.

Project Title: To make educational app for constructed wetland with signage.
Project Description: it can educate the community on storm water management issues/conservation.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Develop an app and great onsite signage for the the constructed wetland.
Project Description: Many people who accidentally find this wonderful park don't appreciate the valuable role this wetland is providing.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Purchase more vehicles with tree-watering capacity.
Project Description:
Too often the City's sidewalk trees don't thrive or just die because they don't get sufficient water when they need it.  Constantly replanting new trees is expensive and defeats the purpose of "growing" our green, urban canopy.

& while we're at it, plant/care for more trees.
Project Status: Watering vehicles not eligible - would require operating funds. However, a project for 100 new trees won funding.

Project Title: To fix or buy watering trucks for trees along the streets.
Project Description: Reduce heat effects, health of our environment.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds. The City contracts with a private company to water trees for two years after planting. Residents can also request tree gators.

Project Title: Recycling wastebaskets
Project Description: Solar compactors don't recycle!
Project Status: This is an ongoing growing Public Works program.

Project Title: Spread composting to more areas.
Project Status: This is an ongoing growing Public Works program. In FY16, curbside organics collection will expand to the entire Monday collection route.

Project Title: Fulmore Park needs to plant trees near playground.
Project Description: We couldn't avoid sunlight so we were exhausted very quickly. If they had trees, many children and others could rest under the trees while playing outside.
Project Status: A project to plant 100 new trees (including in Cambridgeport) won funding.

Project Title: 1,000 Trees for Cambridge!
Project Description:
Combining 2 proposals & adding detail, I propose planting 1,000 trees throughout the city & purchase of equip to water for 2 summers when theyre most fragile. 

The city could identify streets with the least canopy to focus where benefits are greatest. As NYC proposed, we can plant in every possible location, not only replace dead trees. City, CHA & back-of-sidewalk locations are eligible.

Were losing our large legacy trees & new saplings cannot keep up. Yet trees benefit us by:
- providing shade, keeping people, buildings & homes cooler
- reducing storm-water & "heat island effect," lowering AC use & GHG emissions, saving $ in sync with Net Zero efforts
- sequestering GHGs, removing pollutants & adding oxygen
- reducing asthma, lowering stress & other health benefits
- making our urban landscape more pleasant
- providing habitat & connecting us to ecosystems

Trees could be marked as funded via PB so the info & benefits of tree planting are distributed around the City.
Project Status: A scaled-back version of this project won funding! 100 new trees will be planted in FY16 (in addition to the trees Public Works was already planning to plant).

Project Title: Funding for street trees
Project Description: The tree canopy in the city is disappearing due to lack of 1:1 or greater than replacement of removed trees.  Also there is an increased impervious surface as the city increases in density, and greater percentage of the lots are covered in buildings and asphalt.  The advantage of using these funds for trees is that they can be spent in every part of the city!
Project Status: This project won funding! 100 new trees will be planted in FY16 (in addition to the trees Public Works was already planning to plant).

Project Title: A woodland restoration project at Fresh Pond
Project Description: This is an ongoing volunteer project to create a healthy native ecosystem for the animals living at Fresh Pond.  The Water Department helps us, but we need a small amount of money for materials and additional plants.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Plant evergreen trees to hide wired fence Tokyo parking lot that runs up Vassal Lane to Freshpond.
Project Description: The Tokyo Parking lot is agent to The Tobin School, right across an entrance to FreshPond and the start of the Vassal Lane residential neighborhood. Currently old broken down cars are parked there. There is no reason teachers, students, parents,walkers of Freshpond have to be confronted with this sad sight. A line of evergreens is a simple low cost solution to beautifying this stretch.
Project Status: Not eligible - not public property.

Project Title: Proper Pruning of Trees Near Electric Wires
Project Description: On streets with above ground wires neither the city or private landscape companies will prune back trees that are dangerously interacting with electrical wires. It is left to NSTAR to "prune" the trees back. However, NSTAR is more invested in their wires than the trees.They cut off all branches on either side of the wires. A gaping hole of cut off limbs in the middle remains and the shape of the tree becomes like a Y. This is structurally not sound for the tree as it matures. I'd like to see the establishment of a policy on how to properly prune trees near wires that protects the wires AND the trees. NSTAR should be expected to pay a fine ( that goes toward tree care ) if they violate the policy.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Hanging planters in the Inman Square business district
Project Description: It will improve the vibrancy and attractiveness of Inman Square and draw more business to the area.
Project Status: Not eligible - operating cost would exceed capital cost.

Project Title: public bathrooms in Central Square
Project Description: people urinate outside the Pearl Street entrance of the library.
Project Status: This project won funding!

Project Title: public restroom
Project Description: There are no accessible restrooms during peak times spring through fall
Project Status: This project won funding for a public toilet in Central Square!

Project Title: Public restrooms
Project Description: Cambridge was voted "most walkable city" in 2014. Thousands visit Central Sq and Harvard Sq every day but unfortunately there is no public restrooms for people to use. There are some business restrooms but a city like Cambridge should provide free public restrooms and water fountains.
Project Status: This project won funding for a public toilet in Central Square!

Project Title: Mini-dog areas
Project Description: The grass gets ruined at the entrances to parks because so many dogs use those areas. Instead of leaving bare dirt there, put in mini dog areas with the material used in dog parks, waste disposal bags and barrels, and a bench.
Project Status: Budget Delegates prioritized a project for a dog park in East Cambridge, but it did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Flowers/Planters on the Mass Ave Median Strips (islands in the middle of the avenue)
Project Description: I suggest we put planters on the islands between the two sides of Massachusetts Avenue - like Park Avenue in NYC. It is such a high traffic street, between cars, pedestrians and bikers, it seems like it would make life more pleasant and beautiful for all who pass that way, especially now that the sidewalks have been expanded along Mass Ave between Harvard Square and Porter and more of us will be sitting outside on the new seating and restaurant tables, looking at the avenue when the warm weather returns. I would also suggest leaving periodic breaks in the planters so that pedestrians can still cross over at non-crosswalk locations when no traffic is coming in either direction.
Project Status: Not eligible - operating cost would exceed capital cost. Budget Delegates researched and found that the upper Mass. Avenue street improvements plan includes plantings in front of Harvard Law School, in front of the Lesley University building nearest to Porter Square, and on some of the sidewalks.

Project Title: Solar-powered phone charging stations
Project Description: We should have solar-powered phone charging stations about every 5 streets or so in Cambridge so that people can charge their phones when they run out of battery. Some of these stations could also have telephone booths for people who lose their phone or who don't have cell phones.
Project Status: The City already has a grant for solar-powered Wi-Fi benches with phone charging capability.

Project Title: Fund the capital improvement ideas that have been submitted through neighborhood planning processes
Project Description: We should not upend the planning processes of the past. There are many capital improvement ideas that the community put forward that have been waiting for $ for years, they should all be written up by the committee and brought to a vote
Project Status: Not a specific capital idea.

Project Title: I am submitting the idea of a green revolving loan fund, though the idea is not mine.
Project Description: The climate crisis nicely frames the wide array of problems we have, from poorly insulated homes that are expensive to heat to dilapidated roads that make bicycling a challenge. The green revolving loan fund would put money directly into projects that reduce emissions while improving the life of Cambridge residents. The trick is that savings from investments (like reduced heating and cooling costs) get reinvested in the revolving fund.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds.

Project Title: Water Bubbler in the Area IV Youth Center
Project Description: The Area IV Youth Center and local community could benefit from having two new water bubbler with better quality of water. Currently Area IV doesn't match the standards of the other youth centers that provide purified water to the youth, staff and community.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds (maintenance cost). This idea was shared with the Department of Human Services.

Project Title: Drinking Fountains at more intersections and public parks
Project Description: it is needed more.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Install bathrooms at or near Riverside Park
Project Description: Many people who use the park may also need to use the bathroom, but there are none nearby.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. However, a project to install a public toilet in Central Square won funding.

Project Title: Public Restrooms in Central Square 1) on Mass. Ave. behind the old coop and 2) behind City Hall
Project Description: There are not a lot of public restrooms available in this area.  Many stores are not open 24/7.
Project Status: This project won funding for a public toilet in Central Square!

Project Title: Public restrooms
Project Status: This project won funding for a public toilet in Central Square!

Project Title: Public restroom in Central Square
Project Description: The only restrooms are private and people need to buy something in order to use them, but sometimes people don't have money and need to use a restroom.
Project Status: This project won funding!

Project Title: Bathroom in the subways
Project Description: At Central, Kendall, and Davis Square. Most of the time people need to use the bathroom but can't find one to use.
Project Status: Not eligible - MBTA property. However, a project for a public toilet in Central Square won funding.

Project Title: Bathrooms in the train stations
Project Description: This is needed in Central Square and in other T stops
Project Status: Not eligible - MBTA property. However, a project for a public toilet in Central Square won funding.

Project Title: Put trash barrel here so the drunks might use it instead of throwing there liquor bottles in street
Project Description: The trash generated by the liquor store at the corner is disgusting and dangerous- lots of broken glass as people drink in their cars at the dead end and then throw the bottles out the window-  We are so sick of picking up trash and sweeping up glass- not to mention how horrifying it is that so many drive around drunk!
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. Idea was shared with Public Works.

Project Title: to build a 311 calling system.
Project Description: if they were advertised at bus stops and libraries than it would be easier for people to call while they are on the go and not have to depend on computer access to get information or report a problem.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Shower rooms or portable shower rooms for the homeless
Project Description: Homeless people need to have their dignity. Perhaps we could build these portable showers in a church parking lot?
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds.

Project Title: More on-the-street walking in neighborhoods by police (especially dangerous areas) with regular police;
Project Description: more interaction with the community, including meetings.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds. Idea was shared with the Police Department.

Project Title: Security Cameras
Project Description: near 388 Evereteze Way.  My car was recently broken into by people looking for money.  Cameras will help improve safety.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Construct or modernize current structures to provide heated shelter to homeless
Project Description: Sadly, homelessness is a chronic issue in Harvard Square and elsewhere in Cambridge (the state, and the nation). Not all those who are homeless feel comfortable or safe accessing homeless shelters, including homeless youth(http://www.hks.harvard.edu/news-events/news/articles/wilson-on-homelessness-in-harvard-square). While short and long-term shelter, health services, prevention strategies, and other supports are crucial to combating homelessness, they don't meet the criteria for this project. On top of that, we must also address the immediate and most basic needs of those on the streets in our community. Hopefully provided some kind of heated structures on the streets will help provide our homeless "neighbors" with some relief.
Project Status: Budget Delegates researched this idea, but found that the City already provides emergency heating on very cold days to those in need. They looked into heated bus shelters, but most of the bus shelters in Cambridge are owned by a private company.

Project Title: Install water portable water bottle fill stations in City Hall and other public buildings
Project Description: Decreases use of one time plastic water bottles, saves residents money, and supports our environmental goals.  These are being put in building across the nation right now.  Good time to retro fit our water bubblas
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Place generators for emergency response at sites which can meet basic needs of residents.
Project Description: In case of an emergency such as hurricane, we need sites which can respond to basic needs, e.g. distribute critical supplies, charge batteries, etc. City should identify  businesses (e.g. bodegas) and community centers (e.g. East End House, Cambridge Community Center) to fill this role and equip them appropriately.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. City already has some designated emergency sites in City buildings.

Project Title: Repair flooding problems at T stations in Cambridge
Project Description: It is dangerous for T users of the Central Square, Harvard Square, Porter Square, Kendall, Alewife, Davis, train stations.
Project Status: Not eligible - MBTA property.

Project Title: Security cameras in dangerous places in Cambridge
Project Description: This will increase safety and help the police solve crimes.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To build more playgrounds in Cambridge.
Project Description: older people and children need more program.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Mini-dog areas
Project Description: The grass gets ruined at the entrances to parks because so many dogs use those areas. Instead of leaving bare dirt there, put in mini dog areas with the material used in dog parks, waste disposal bags and barrels, and a bench.
Project Status: Budget Delegates prioritized a project for a dog park in East Cambridge, but it did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: A shower with space for storing belongings used by persons who are homeless.
Project Description: With the closing of Bread & Jams last June, persons who are homeless lost access to a safe place to shower.  The day shelter, which was located in Harvard Square, served approximately 55 people daily. A shower located on city-owned property in Central Square would address a significant unmet need.  I would also like to propose that the city expand the participatory budgeting process next year to include the funding of services.
Project Status: Budget Delegates found that showers and locked spaces are already available in some Cambridge shelters.

Project Title: More water fountains throughout the City
Project Description: People need water and there are not enough fountains
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Indoor smoking areas
Project Description: in parks or near public housing.  With no smoking rules people get in trouble.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Guard rails at T stations so no one falls on tracks
Project Description: Public safety
Project Status: Not eligible - MBTA property.

Project Title: Promote Establishments that Graciously Allow the Public to use their  Bathrooms.
Project Description: In exchange for free advertisement and a stipend businesses would agree to make their bathrooms available to the public. Ideally they would be scattered around the city. In congested areas several establishments would participate to prevent over use at one location. They could be listed in city publications. If there was a walking trail guide, for example, they could be listed and recognized for their bathroom hospitality.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds. However, a project to install a public toilet in Central Square won funding.

Project Title: More enclosed off-leash dog parks
Project Description: Many dog owners in Cambridge; however only 2 or 3 dog parks allow dogs off-leash (Danehy, Fresh Pond, and Fort Washington (which is not enclosed)
Project Status: The project on the ballot for a dog park (in East Cambridge) did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Make a Dog Park in Mid-Cambridge
Project Description: The library functions as an unofficial dog park. While that is great, having a legal off-leash area in mid-Cambridge would be a better solution.
Project Status: The project on the ballot for a dog park (in East Cambridge) did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Build a dog park
Project Description: Dogs using the general park in that is unsanitary/ a health hazard for residents.
Project Status: The project on the ballot for a dog park (in East Cambridge) did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Off-leash hours for dogs in Sacramento Field.
Project Description: There are few places in the Agassiz Neighborhood to have a dog off-leash.  It is necessary for dogs to have a chance to exercise freely. Being off-leash under the supervision of their owner is also important in training and socializing dogs properly.
Project Status: This is not a capital project, but the idea was shared with the Open Space Committee.

Project Title: Locate an off leash dog park on a portion of the city hall lawn
Project Description: The city does not enforce dog regulations on Sennott Park, so perhaps those who violate regulations would move to an off leash park at city hall, and perhaps they would clean up if they were watched by the city manager.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Enclose the open space next to playground for dogs
Project Description: There is no fenced in area in Mid-Cambridge or Area 4 where a visually impaired person can give his/her seeing eye dog opportunity to run off leash. Dogs use this space already.
Project Status: Budget Delegates prioritized a project for a dog park in East Cambridge, but it did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Mini-dog areas
Project Description: The grass gets ruined at the entrances to parks because so many dogs use those areas. Instead of leaving bare dirt there, put in mini dog areas with the material used in dog parks, waste disposal bags and barrels, and a bench.
Project Status: Budget Delegates prioritized a project for a dog park in East Cambridge, but it did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Mini-dog areas
Project Description: The grass gets ruined at the entrances to parks because so many dogs use those areas. Instead of leaving bare dirt there, put in mini dog areas with the material used in dog parks, waste disposal bags and barrels, and a bench.
Project Status: Budget Delegates prioritized a project for a dog park in East Cambridge, but it did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Benches and dog areas at entrances to Russell Field.
Project Description: Russell Field has a wide open area at Harvey Street where people often sit on the grass. It would be better, especially for older peoppeople, to have benches to sit on. It's a great area for a pocket park.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: A Multitude of Dog Leash Law Signs in Cambridge City Parks
Project Description:
The City of Cambridge is failing to enforce the leashing law in its public parks, and I do not feel safe.   The long-term consequence of this lack of enforcement is a growing sense of entitlement among dogs owners to do whatever they want.  In Danehy Park the only sign I could find is a list of park regulations that appears at only the main entrances to the park in tiny letters. 

My suggestion is to add signs to every other lamppost in Danehy that say: "All dogs must be on a leash at all times.  Violators are subject to up to a $200 fine.  A dog-run is available in the Northwest corner of the park."  

Analogous signs should be added widely to all parks.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.
Entities: A Multitude of Dog Leash Law Signs,Cambridge City Parks

Project Title: Improvements to Larch park - keep pets out, make play area safer
Project Description: There are a lot of incidents with pets and children; equipment is broken in park
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Improvements at the Clarendon Ave tot lot/park
Project Description: The brick wall along mass ave is crumbling and needs to be fixed.  Also the water fountain needs to be fixed/improved (install the kind that can fill water bottles).  The "sand area" could also be cleaned and refresed with new sand.  The mass ave corner is a favorite hang-out for many of the senior citizens from the burns, so perhaps improve that area as well (must maintain the tree shade). Install a real (or Junior) basketball hoop in the circle so older kids could use the park in the evening.
Project Status: Budget Delegates researched this idea, but found that the City is already planning improvements at this location.

Project Title: To build a fence around Lowell Park.
Project Description: it can increase park safety and usage.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Less Oppressive Barrier (near Fresh Pond)
Project Description: The chain-link fence surrounding the pond is oppressive and detracts from the experience of enjoying this amenity. A much lower and better designed barrier would serve the same purpose, and enhance the park-like experience.
Project Status: Budget Delegates researched this idea, but found that it was not feasible since the fence is protecting the water supply.

Project Title: Add a fence to keep children away from the Parkway
Project Description: No one uses this park, particularly if they have pets or young children, because there is nothing preventing them from wandering into traffic. A simple, good-looking fence would protect young park users without detracting from the park's scenic nature.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: New park entrance on Walden Street
Project Description: Make use of the city-owned parcel at this location to connect the park to Walden Street.
Project Status: Not feasible - City-owned parcel leads to private property, so there is no through connection to the park.

Project Title: New entrance to the park (Danehy)
Project Description: The entrance is right onto the road and the sidewalk is narrow. And it's a great park!!
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Improve playground at Tobin (for lower and upper elementary schools)
Project Description: This playground is tired and sad. The trees that were planted several years ago are all nearly dead and consequently, there is no shade which renders this playground practically OPPRESSIVE during late spring and summer. There is also limited place in which to sit. This park space could greatly benefit from new plantings (and a commitment/plan by the city to water them), more benches near the school building where parents congregate while their kid(s) are at play.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. This location was recently renovated.

Project Title: More participatory play structures at Tobin
Project Description:
Please consider purchasing this great play equipment for Tobin and other parks.

it would be great to have this in the tobin park: 

Rigamajig -- this a 200 piece large format construction kit that empowers kids to build unique structures.

It could be stored in a small box in the playground.

Rigamajig | www.rigamajig.com
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Upgrade School parks at Amigos & FMA
Project Description: inadequate equipment
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: An improved playground for the Amigos School
Project Description: It would create enough safe playground space for students at recess and improve the community playground space for the neighborhood.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Park Renovations and safety lights for Cambridgeport school playground
Project Description: The school playground has unfortunately had issues with people spending the night, urinating and defecating on the playground at night causing rancid smells at the least and health safety concerns for children who play here by day. By installing motion sensor lighting especially in the rear which is often sight unseen we could deter unwanted nighttime activity. Along with a thorough cleaning and freshening up the playground (painting, new flooring etc) would be a much healthier environment for kids, teachers and parents.
Project Status: The Cambridgeport School playground has been funded for renovation through the Community Preservation Act.

Project Title: Spruce up playgrounds
Project Description: A lot of playgrounds need improvements this spring. Specifically, Raymond Park needs new sand. Graham and Parks school needs a new playground altogether (that tiny playground serves 400+ kids!!) and definitely needs tons more wood chips just to make it a safe play area.
Project Status: The Graham and Parks playground is scheduled to be resurfaced this summer.

Project Title: Improve playground off Garden st, acroos from the Lincoln Way apartments
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To add a Football field to Danehy Park
Project Description: The park is all grass and a lot of baseball fields and it would be a good place to have football practice
Project Status: Not feasible - too expensive.

Project Title: Add Lights and Renovate Playground at Glacken Field
Project Description: Glacken Field is a beautiful soccer/baseball field next to the Fresh Pond Golf Course.  People go there from all over Cambridge and from the local neighborhood, and we are always staying way past dark.  Add some lights and this field will get even more use, and renovate the playground too!  Now there are a lot of little kids in the area and this playground is old and a little below Cambridge standards...
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Improve Playground and Field Conditions at Raymond Park
Project Description: Raymond Park serves as a nexus of community activity and connection, drawing people from the immediate neighborhood and beyond. I propose some enhancements to make the space more usable and safe for all users.The current grading of the field results in muddy floodingthat limits use of the park fields for much of the year. The play structures should be updated to engage a wider range of children.There is space to expand the community garden area to address the long waiting list of potential gardeners and even to construct a childrens garden. The exit to busy Walden Street should be reconfigured to make it safer for small children.
Project Status: A scaled back version of this project (to improve the community garden at Raymond Park) made it to the ballot, but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Create a water feature in Raymond Park
Project Description: It's too hot for kids to play in the summer
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Add more swings to Peabody School Park
Project Description: They are needed because the swings are always taken and they need to be higher off the ground
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Add an indoor swimming pool to MLK School
Project Description: So everybody can learn how to swim.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds and is too expensive.

Project Title: Build playground and park for children/families
Project Description: In this area, there are not enough safe places for young children to play.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Build a better playground (right outside Main Library)
Project Description: Playground is small and needs maintenance
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Create a larger play area at
Project Description: At the Benjamin Banneker Charter Public School the kids don't have a safe area to play in. We could improve the school by adding a bigger space to play basketball, football, soccer, etc...
Project Status: Charter schools are not eligible for this funding.

Project Title: Expand & modernize Larch Park
Project Description: Park is old & small. It's not safe
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Linear Park
Project Description: Fix low spot (between Cameron and Davis Sq.) where it overflows and in winter ices up - very unsafe! (Must we wait for a major lawsuit?)
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: A Public Park on this Abandoned, City-owned Lot
Project Description: Why does the City not do something with this empty lot it owns on the corner of Concord Avenue and Spinelli Place. Currently, it appears to be reserved for a large sign advertising area businesses. We can do MUCH better. At a minimum, this space should have a Hubway station, benches, nice plantings, etc.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: TBD capital idea to make use of underutilized Vellucci Park
Project Description: This park is located in a prime space but is underutilized.  We need a solution that will improve the vibrancy of the area and draw more people to Inman Square.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: More lights around running path at Fresh Pond Circle
Project Description: It's not safe to run in the evening
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Light sensors and surface repair for tennis courts at Hoyt Field and Riverside Park
Project Description: The lights are off at night, but having light sensors would allow people to use the courts after dark while also conserving energy when the courts are not in use.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.
Entities: Light sensors,surface repair,tennis courts,Riverside Park,Hoyt Field

Project Title: Vest-pocket park near Leslie University Porter Square.
Project Description: The benches that have been placed on Roseland Street as a 'green-space' by Leslie University for the neighborhood are on a narrow strip between a parking lot and a busy street.  This 'park' does not substantively address the need for public green space in the neighborhood. The only other 'park' in the area is the MBTA's concrete plaza at the Porter Square stop.
Project Status: Not eligible - not public property.

Project Title: Use part of city-owned DPW land to provide playground/park in this dense neighborhood
Project Description: This very dense neighborhood has no playground without kids crossing many busy streets.  It is sad to see so much wealth and development and still no playground- My own children & neighbors played on sidewalks and in the street- It would benefit all residents and create a much healthier environment for children- many who have no yards to play in.- just look how unequally parks are distributed thru Cambridge- more parks are in less dense areas, none here.
Project Status: Not feasible - space required for DPW operations.

Project Title: Seating to enjoy the beautiful view around Jerry's Pond near Russell Field in North Cambridge
Project Description: Jerry's Pond in North Cambridge is one of the most beautiful spots in our City.  But surrounded by a chain link fence with no clearing for seating and no lookout, it is difficult to appreciate the way the old growth trees frame the water and the swans, wild turkeys, other water fowl that inhabit the area. A bench or two facing the water (either contiguous with the parking area for Russell Field, or along the path between the field house and the Alewife T Station) is suggested to provide peaceful relaxation and educational nature watching family activity.
Project Status: Not eligible - MBTA property.

Project Title: Lots more benches at Fresh Pond
Project Description: Right now there is almost no place to sit down and enjoy the surroundings and rest while walking.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Install picnic benches and moveable chairs on the lawn in front of city hall
Project Description: This would help create community interaction on the green space, especially for those who can't just being picnic blankets or lay on the grass.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Artificial turf in Sennott Park in the playing area and additional benches
Project Description: The city is unable to maintain the grass and more people would like to sit on benches with backs
Project Status: Not eligible - too expensive.

Project Title: Educational Park
Project Description: The City needs a public space where people can come together to learn about ecology and environmental issues and experiment with sustainability solutions.  This type of "educational park" could be located somewhere near the river and would not need to be staffed.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Improve signage for Magazine Beach
Project Description: There is no signage for the park.  More signage is needed on Memorial Drive, Magazine Street, and the surrounding area.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Develop sculptural play/climbing areas/experiences in and around the trees at Magazine Beach Park
Project Description: There is no playground at the park. Thousands are drawn there each summer to swim and picnic along the Charles River. This is Cambridge's 2nd largest park! It ain't going to happen w/o Cambridge and DCR will probably match Cambridge dollars!
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Fitness park
Project Description: Similar to the Charles River workout station - encourage exercise, no gym membership required!
Project Status: This project made it to the ballot (location was moved to Danehy Park), but did not receive enough votes to win funding.
