Project Title: Exercise equipment
Project Description:
There's only one set of exercise equipment in the Cambridge parks.  Chicago has them all along Lake Michigan and I think they are a great public benefit.
This stretch of the Fresh Pond path would be perfect to setup a few well-spaced stations.  You can also include some signage for people explaining the various exercises.
-Pull-up bar
-Inverted row bars
-Parallel bars
-Dip station
-Inclined leg-raises
-Sit-ups
-Slanted wooden fence for jumping over
-Something for plyometrics
-Back extension

You might be able to recruit someone looking for an eagle scout project to assist.

For an example, using Street View in Google Maps, start at the Diversey Miniature Golf Course in Chicago and head north on the gravel running path.
Project Status: This project made it to the ballot (location was moved to Danehy Park), but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: StayFitCambridge! Modern Body-Weight Fitness Stations
Project Description: Life-long fitness is important and our already amazing green spaces could use spaces that encourage adults to pursue fitness (strength, flexibility, and fitness). Leading parks in the country have already proven this is a successful idea. For an example, read about Piedmont Park, Atlanta, Georgia. [This idea has a PowerPoint that was submitted with it via email - see Google drive]
Project Status: This project made it to the ballot, but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Add pull-up bars in parks and playgrounds.
Project Description: It would be great to add the option of upper body exercise when  going for a run.
Project Status: This project made it to the ballot (for outdoor fitness equipment in Danehy Park), but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Indoor Playspace in multi area's of Camb with gross motor toys for winter fun for parents & Caregive
Project Description: It is the most inportant thing for a child to be able to move there bodies and exercise at all times of the year.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds.

Project Title: Concrete Ping Pong tables
Project Description: Everybody loves ping pong!
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Concrete Ping-pong tables or permanent grill

Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Public gyms
Project Description: near charter schools without gyms.  Kids need safe physical activity.
Project Status: Budget Delegates felt that this idea could be addressed by the project for fitness equipment in Danehy Park, which made it to the ballot but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Install a second basket and backboard And a permanent fountain to replace the "temporary" one that b
Project Description: Need to replace the missing basket and backboard. Also a permanent water fountain was promised to replace the junky temporary one on the side of the school that rarely works. Cambridgeport school/community playground

Project Title: Improve lighting on the basketball courts and improve other conditions for expanded use of the space
Project Description: More lighting would increase use for evening sports, music, dance parties etc on the staging area in the back of the teen car and the court area

Project Title: Solar-powered, heated bus shelters on Mass. Ave. from the bridge to Harvard
Project Description: Using solar panels to heat bus shelters in the winter would give people a warm, dry space while they waited for the bus.  Bus shelters could also be made more ADA accessible, especially by making sure that all snow is removed during the winter.
Project Status: Most bus shelters are not eligible because they are owned by a private company. Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Bus shelter
Project Description: Many of the seniors in the area have requested a bus shelter here for the popular (but always late) MBTA bus 69.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Benches at all bus stops and shelters at the main ones, such as at the Harvard gates
Project Status: Most bus shelters are not eligible because they are owned by a private company. Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Build bus stop shelters and benches
Project Description: A lot of Cambridge Rindge and Latin high school students and college students wait for buses in that area
Project Status: Community Development Department (CDD) informed Budget Delegates that more bus shelters are coming to the city, but specific locations were not yet finalized. This idea was shared with CDD.

Project Title: Bus shelter with a bench and screen that shows when the next bus is coming
Project Description: I wait a long time for at this bus stop, but there is nowhere to sit and there is not protection from the rain, snow, sun, etc.  I use this bus and wait at this bus station every weekend, but the bus only comes once an hour, so I have to wait a long time.  A shelter with a bench and a screen showing when the next bus is coming would help me a lot.
Project Status: An idea to put real-time arrival monitors in bus shelters made it to the ballot, but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Install any new shelters with rubber bench seats with better protection from elements.
Project Description: The current shelters provide little protection from wind, rain , and snow.  In addition the seats are either too cold, too hot, or too wet most of the year.  There are better glass shelters available (also with advertisements to make them affordable.)  San Francisco has such shelters. Check them out.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. The Community Development Department informed them that the composition of bus shelters would be determined by Cemusa.

Project Title: A cross town separated bike lane so people could bike from Ailwife to East Cambridge
Project Description: Biking is an important part of the transportation system and separated bike lanes make cycling safer for everyone.
Project Status: Not eligible - too expensive.

Project Title: A cycle track on River Street
Project Description: People traveling from Central Square/East Cambridge to Lower Allston will (probably) take Western Ave. Then, coming back, not only do they have to brave Soldiers Field Road, but there is no comparable cycle track to make them feel safe on a road that receives comparable throughput.
Project Status: Not eligible - too expensive.  City is working on a plan to get the reconstruction of River Street into the five-year capital budget.  Design of streets, sidewalk, and bicycle accommodation would be part of the community process.

Project Title: Bicycle Signage: Signs at intersections telling bicyclists they must follow traffic rules
Project Description: As a driver, pedestrian and bicyclist I see way too many bicyclers ignore traffic rules that sooner or later will result in accident and injury. Cyclers should stop at red lights, stop signs etc. They should not make illegal turns etc.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Bike air pump and small tools at the Central Square Branch Library
Project Description: There are not any bike air pumps in the Central Square area.  There are bike air pumps and tools you can use to fix your bike on the MIT campus and it's very useful, so we could use the same thing in Central Square.
Project Status: This project won funding! 8 bike repair stations will be installed around Cambridge.
Entities: Bike air pump,tools,Central Square Branch Library

Project Title: Bike lane/cycle track on Webster Ave.
Project Description: A bike lane would help make this street safer for cyclists.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Bike lanes on Prospect Street
Project Description:
Prospect Street is scary and stressful. Wow.

It's a major street for cars and bikes, and yet a good portion of it is taken up by a protected turn lane that is blocked off for half the street, leading up to the Whole Foods. Heading into Central Square the curb is raised so even if I needed to escape a close, angry car, I wouldn't be able to. Obviously there is not a lot of width (outside that darn turn lane) but something needs to be done on this street.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Bike racks
Project Description: There are not enough bike racks in this area.  As a result, you see bikes parked in handicap spots and at parking meters near the T.
Project Status: Budget Delegates discussed bike racks and bike parking at length, and a bike rack/parking idea made it to their semi-final list, but other suggestions were ranked as higher priority. The Community Development Department's capital budget contains two additional years of funds at $33,000/year for special bike parking projects.

Project Title: To have education bike signage throughout the city, especially in Inman Square.
Project Description: it will increase the safety of bicyclists, pedestrians, and motor vehicle drivers.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Bike racks
Project Description: There are not enough bike racks near the Coop.  You see lots of bikes parked in handicap spots and at parking meters near the T as a result.
Project Status: Budget Delegates discussed bike racks and bike parking at length, and a bike rack/parking idea made it to their semi-final list, but other suggestions were ranked as higher priority. The Community Development Department's capital budget contains two additional years of funds at $33,000/year for special bike parking projects.

Project Title: Bike racks
Project Description: There are not enough bike racks in this area
Project Status: Budget Delegates discussed bike racks and bike parking at length, and a bike rack/parking idea made it to their semi-final list, but other suggestions were ranked as higher priority. The Community Development Department's capital budget contains two additional years of funds at $33,000/year for special bike parking projects.

Project Title: Covered bicycle parking with solar-powered lighting
Project Description:
Cycling is on the rise in Cambridge, but not all residents find it practical to bring their bikes inside at the end of the day.  Covered outdoor parking sprinkled through the city's neighborhoods would combine the convenience of leaving your bike outside with protection from the elements and rust.  While sidewalk space is at a premium, there are many suitable sites (especially near intersections) where covered parking for 4-8 bikes could be installed without obstructing pedestrian and wheelchair access.   The most useful place to have the racks would be in the middle of dense residential neighborhoods, rather than in commercial squares.

The participatory budget would fund a pilot program for installing several covered bike racks in neighborhoods and then collecting feedback from cyclists who use them.  Based on the use patterns for the covered parking and cyclist satisfaction level, the City could then evaluate installing them on a more widespread basis in every neighborhood.
Project Status: Budget Delegates discussed bike racks and bike parking at length, and a bike rack/parking idea made it to their semi-final list, but other suggestions were ranked as higher priority. The Community Development Department's capital budget contains two additional years of funds at $33,000/year for special bike parking projects.

Project Title: Cycle track (protected bike lane)
Project Description: Mass. Ave. is dangerous for bikers.  We need a cycle track (protected bike lane) on Mass. Ave. northbound after Harvard, similar to the one on Western Ave.
Project Status: Not eligible - too expensive.

Project Title: Educational program for bikers like they have for drivers - "Biker's Ed"
Project Description: Bikers often go beyond the limits and don't respect cars, but a program educating them about proper road rules would help prevent a lot of accidents.  The program could be held at Cambridge libraries, the high school, or the Community Learning Center.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds.

Project Title: Extend the cycle track beyond Western Ave
Project Description: Mass Ave is dangerous for bikers, so it would be great to extend the cycle track (protected bike lane) beyond Western Ave. to improve safety.
Project Status: Not eligible - too expensive.  City is working on a plan to get the reconstruction of River Street (which would include this area) into the five-year capital budget.  Design of streets, sidewalk, and bicycle accommodation would be part of the community process.

Project Title: Grand Junction multi-use Path
Project Description: To connect the Minuteman/Linear/Community bike highway with E.C./W.H., Kendall/MIT, Mass. Av., C'port, River paths, BU, and Allston will reduce GHG pollution, increase health, reduce bike/car accidents, and enhance the city and region. The money could be used to design and begin implementation.
Project Status: Not eligible - too expensive, but Community Development Department study is underway.

Project Title: Install bike racks
Project Description: There are not enough in this area of Cambridge
Project Status: Budget Delegates discussed bike racks and bike parking at length, and a bike rack/parking idea made it to their semi-final list, but other suggestions were ranked as higher priority. The Community Development Department's capital budget contains two additional years of funds at $33,000/year for special bike parking projects.

Project Status: This is not as simple as just adding a bike lane.  Significant improvements were made by removing a general purpose lane a few years ago, giving more space to cyclists. Inman Square traffic study to improve the area will begin in spring 2015.

Project Title: Windsor and Mass Ave

Project Title: Mist Sprinklers on Sidewalks
Project Description: These would cool people off on hot days.

Project Title: Make Hampshire & Cambridge Streets into Grand Boulevard w bike lanes and wide sidewalks
Project Description: Make Cambridge st & Hampshire each oneway (going different directions) (either from Inman Square all the way east or at least from Inman to Columbia) This makes it possible to remove a lane of traffic, and to widen sidewalks & tree wells, to created dedicated bike lanes make traffic slow down in these residential neighborhoods where commuters often drive too fast. This will help stores, pedestrians bicyclers, residents, and local drivers. The inman Sq intersections would be more sane and the streets & sidewalks much better looking. (And then people won't be biking in the sidewalks!!!)

Project Status: Budget Delegates discussed bike racks and bike parking at length, and a bike rack/parking idea made it to their semi-final list, but other suggestions were ranked as higher priority. Project Title: Outdoor tools for fixing bikes and more bike racks
Project Description: (No specific location specified)

Project Title: Protect the Bike Lane on Harvard Bridge!

Project Title: Separate bike lanes throughout Cambridge, especially on Mass. Ave.

Project Status: Not eligible - not City property (belongs to state).

At the same time, this is a critical route between Cambridge and Somerville for cyclists. Let's repurpose that space into a separated bike lane with trees to make better public space for everyone.

Project Title: To add bike lanes.
Project Description: it increases safety.

Project Title: Turn this part of JFK street into a pedestrian mall.
Project Description: Harvard Square should be a more pedestrian friendly space.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Use grass pave on infrequently used roads
Project Description: Storwater runoff is a big problem and permeable pavements can provide a potential solution. There is even technology that allows roads to be "paved" with grass. The city could experiment with this solution in locations where the road is basically used only by abutters. This would also provide a potentially attractive alternative aesthetic to asphalt, while lowering maintenance costs and increasing green space. A small strip of concrete or asphalt can be maintained for bike travel.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Widen and Light this Sidewalk
Project Description: This narrow sidewalk with a high retaining wall on on side and fenced-in woods on the other side is a popular route between the Russell Field entrance to the Alewife MBTA Station and Rindge Avenue, the Rindge Towers, and the Fresh Pond Malls. It is used as a multi-use path by bike riders (going to and from the Minuteman Bike Path) and pedestrians (going to and from the T). After dark it is totally in the dark. Can this sidewalk be widened and lit to make it safer both for crime prevention and bikes and pedestrians passing each other?
Project Status: Not eligible -  not City property (MassDOT and WR Grace).

Project Title: To repair the sidewalks
Project Description: If we smoothed the sidewalks and repaired the ramps it would help those people who have trouble walking
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Traffic calming - raised crosswalk
Project Description: Windsor St. in general needs a traffic calming solution. Part of this could be achieved through a raised crosswalk at Windsor St. & Lincoln St.  The area is dangerous for bikers.
Project Status: Budget Delegates felt that this is a traffic timing issue and shared the idea with the Traffic Department.

Project Title: Stretchable material on sidewalk covering tree roots
Project Description: for all sidewalks -----Bricks, tar, cement, etc. crack and protrude when tree roots grow beneath them.  Area becomes impassable for wheelchairs and dangerous for any pedestrian.  This fabric would stretch with root growth to keep surface smooth, level, and safe.
Project Status: Kirkland Street is included in the Five-Year Plan for reconstruction.

Project Title: To build a guard rail
Project Description: pedestrians walking along the side of Brattle Street and Fresh Pond Parkway should be protected.
Project Status: Not eligible - not City property.

Project Title: Signs to slow traffic down
Project Description: When children try to cross the street here to go to the park it is very scary.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Solving pedestrian problem in Inman Sq
Project Description:
I also vote to solve the crosswalk lights at Cambridge/Hampshire/Springfield Streets. Today I saw a fight between energetic youths who had the WALK light and a heavy dump truck driver who had speed from running down Beacon St plus the green light at Hampshire and did not want to slow down let alone stop. The startled youths slowed their walking making the speeding truck slow & stop. The driver though he had a green light and was in the right, while the youths had the WALK light.  Daily MADNESS.

The Fire House uses a button to make all traffic lights turn red when fire trucks need right-of-way.  As with other complex city squares, the traffic light system in Inman Square needs to make an all-way stop so that pedestrians can have a safe right-of-way.
Project Status: Budget Delegates felt that this is a traffic timing issue and shared the idea with the Traffic Department.  Inman Square traffic study to improve the area will begin in spring 2015.

Project Title: Speed bumps on Line street
Project Description: Line street is a very busy one way connecting Cambridge and Kirkland st. It is a high traffic road and vehicles often speed through or the occasional cars and motorcycles will race at high speed. Many pedestrians especially elderly and children use this road as it connects to Cambridge hospital and Beacon street as well. There have been several hit and run pedestrian incidents in the last few years and speed bumps would deter speeding and thus avoid future injury and accidents.
Project Status: After visiting the site and taking notes on traffic, Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. The City does not support installation of speed bumps due to emergency vehicle response.

Project Title: Replace the benches on Massachusetts ave that were removed to make way for bike racks
Project Description: People need a place to,sit besides sidewalk cafes
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Responsibility for snowplowing sidewalks
Project Description: I suggest the city take responsibility for (snow)plowing sidewalks.  the cost would be added to real estate taxes presumably, but it could be more effective than the patchwork of clear, snowy, and icy sections we have now, better for this famously  walkable city.
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds.

Project Title: Re-paint & restore fire lane and un-blocked gates at back of DPW yard
Project Description: The fire lane is essential for fire safely of all in this tightly packed neighbrhood- but has been neglected: the white lines on the street need to be re-painted, the 'fire lane" sign is gone from the back gates, and the gates are blocked by rubble, concrete blocks and trucks.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Repainting intersection of Hampshire/Cambridge Street
Project Description: It's incredibly dangerous and confusing! Paint bike lanes that continue through the intersection, for one thing. And create some better wayfinding for people taking a right onto Inman Street, because they're often competing with bicyclists to be on the right-most part of the street. Not only repainting, but reconfiguring the timing of traffic lights and pedestrian signals. There's a 50-second walk signal across Cambridge but at the same moment drivers are trying to head east on Cambridge Street; people shouldn't be looking over their shoulders when they're being told it's safe to walk across the street. Either make the cars wait at a red light or cut the bologna and make the pedestrian walk signal shorter; anything other than letting them go at the same time. Also, on a positive note, I think it would be really fun to have colorfully painted asphalt at Inman Square's most iconic intersection.
Project Status: Budget Delegates felt that this is a traffic timing issue and shared the idea with the Traffic Department.  Inman Square traffic study to improve the area will begin in spring 2015.

Project Title: Repair potholes on Fresh Pond Parkway
Project Description: When you drive, the road is uneven/unstable for cars- the potholes also cause flooding.
Project Status: Not eligible - not City property.

Project Title: Repair upper Tremont and Carlisle and sidewalks
Project Description: Tremont Street between Cambridge and Hampshire has become a major thoroughfare because heavy traffic jams Prospect, Cambridge, and Hampshire so people use Tremont as a go-around. The street is cracked, has potholes, is poorly drained, and has been patched piecemeal. It is not in the DPW master plan for repair, even though it has not been repaved in at least 15 years. The same is true of Carlisle, which feeds into Tremont. Also, the sidewalks on both Tremont and Carlisle are uneven, cracked, randomly patched.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Repave Sherman St.
Project Description: This road is in constant disrepair and consistently has the largest potholes in all of Cambridge.  These potholes pose a significant danger, as drivers swerve onto the other side of the road, narrowly avoiding oncoming traffic, to avoid ruining their shocks on the potholes.
Project Status: Sherman Street between Huron and Walden will be repaved during summer 2015.

Project Title: Raised Crosswalk
Project Description: Drivers constantly disrespect the pedestrian crossing in front of the park entrance. A raised crosswalk would help reduce the driving speed and better mark the entrance to the park.
Project Status: Budget Delegates felt that this is a traffic timing issue and shared the idea with the Traffic Department.

Project Title: Raised median and a dedicated traffic guard
Project Description: The intersection at Inman Square is extremely dangerous.  Having a raised median as well as a traffic guard assigned to direct traffic in this area would increase safety for pedestrians, drivers, and bikers.
Project Status: Adding a traffic guard is not possible, because it would require operating funds. Budget Delegates felt that this is a traffic timing issue and shared the idea with the Traffic Department. Inman Square traffic study to improve the area will begin in spring 2015.

Project Title: Redesign intersection of Rindge Ave and Sherman St.
Project Description: The yellow lines on Rindge at Sherman were redrawn recently. This small change had an oversized impact to traffic and, subsequently, quality of life in my North Cambridge neighborhood. The reason for this is that the previous width of the street allowed cars continuing straight on Rindge Ave to go around those waiting to take a left on Sherman Street. Now, if one car waits to take a left, every other car behind them misses the light as well. This routinely causes backups all the way to the Peabody School. This is a largely residential area, so it impacts residents and those trying to drop their children off at school and make their way to work. My idea has two options: The first is to redraw the double yellow lines to accommodate cars continuing straight on Rindge Ave - so they do not have to wait behind those taking a left on Sherman Street. The second is to add a delayed green light allowing cars to take a left before those traveling the opposite direction get the green light.
Project Status: Budget Delegates felt that this is a traffic timing issue and shared the idea with the Traffic Department.

Project Title: Redesign of Memorial Drive Section
Project Description: There is a great opportunity to rethink how the MIT campus engages with the riverfront. Would be great to expand the public space along the river's edge by reducing the medians and improving pedestrian crossings. Would require working with the DCR abd MIT to make it happen.
Project Status: Not eligible - not City property (belongs to state).

Project Title: Redo sidewalk on south side Mass ave at Central Sq.
Project Description: very icy uneven surface does not let water drain. Also collects garbage and looks ugly. Make it porous so it drains - put in a water cistern for watering plants underneath (Quinton's idea). Central sq deserves just as nice sidewalks as Harvard sq - or even nicer.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Reevaluate the length of the traffic light exiting the Porter Square shopping plaza onto Mass Ave.
Project Description: This light is short and provides a safety hazard as cars gun out of the parking lot so they don't lose a green light but pedestrians and/or bikers are often still in the cross walks having not having realized the light changed.
Project Status: Not eligible - not a capital project. This idea was shared with the Traffic Department.

Project Title: Raised cross walk for traffic calming on Magazine Street
Project Description: Many pedestrians, including school age children and elders, cross Magazine Street daily to access Dana Park. The current crosswalk is faded and not raised and there are no traffic calming strategies in place. Magazine St is a major route for cars, trucks and buses accessing Central Square or Mem Drive. Many vehicles speed and/or drive in the middle of the road, crossing over the yellow line. A raised crosswalk would cause everyone to slow down and also give pedestrians more time to access Dana Park safely. Kids walking to the Amigos School could also cross there safely to get to/from school on Upton Street.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. Traffic Department will restripe crosswalk this year.

Project Title: Banners and wayfinding signs for each commercial district
Project Description: Cambridge is a city with wonderful commercial districts. It would be nice if we had banners for each commercial district (like the ones Harvard Sq has) and wayfinding signs showing people how easily it is to walk from Kendall to Central, Kendall to Cambridge St or North Point, etc. Boston has done a great job with this in their complete streets program: http://bostoncompletestreets.org/whats-new/downtown-bicycle-wayfinding-pilot-program-gets-underway/
Project Status: This idea made it to the ballot, but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Bench-a-Block: Public seating for the Public Realm (with shading options)
Project Description: There are not enough opportunities for people (particularly seniors and people with physical limitations) to sit as they are walking about in the public realm.  And there are definitely FEW opportunities for sitting in shade.  The few shaded public benches are always the first ones to be taken up for long periords of time on hot days!
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Better markings and lightings on crosswalks, especially on Broadway
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Better night lighting for crosswalks
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Better traffic light timing, changed for different rush houes and for nights (much more frequent changes)
Project Status: This is not a capital project, but the idea was shared with the Traffic Department.

Project Title: Build Sidewalk
Project Description: This section of Bay State does not have any sidewalks on the right hand side of the road. The lack of a curb causes drivers to regularly park right against fences (particularly at Bonnie's gardening shop) leaving no space for pedestrians. Very dangerous.
Project Status: Bay State Road reconstruction is designed to include a sidewalk here.

Project Title: Change the timing and cycles for crossing/walking/biking/driving through Inman Square
Project Description:
This is one the most frustrating, if not dangerous, intersections in the City. My suggestion is a barn dance configuration.              1. Independent Pedestrian crossings would last one minute and would include diagonal crosswalks. 2. One cycle would just be for all left turns of cars with clear demarcated bike lanes 3.One cycle for all right turns, clear bike lanes with turning arrows.  Pedestrians would also be allowed to cross straight as cars/bike would ONLY go straight during those cycles.
Serious educational outreach before changes; warnings during early employment; finally, strict enforcement for peds, bikes and cars  who crossed at wrong times.
Project Status: Inman Square traffic study to improve the area will begin  in spring 2015. This idea was shared with the Traffic Department.

Project Title: More light in the street by the Charles River
Project Description: It's too dark
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Clearly mark the Sommerville/ Cambridge city line on Roseland Street.
Project Description: It is easy to get confused and receive a $50 parking violation from the Sommerville police.  The city line is clearly marked on most of the other streets in the area e.g. Oxford Street.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. The Traffic Department will review the signs.

Project Title: Complete re-do/re-design of the "shared path" between Russell Field House and Alewife T headhouse
Project Description: (The path next to Jerry's Pit.)  The current features are ugly and ineffective; pedestrians are not safe.  We could change signage, paint jobs, and overall design to benefit all users, including bikers who currently race through the area, endangering pedestrians.
Project Status: Not eligible - not City property. The City is currently working with the property owner (WR Grace) and the MBTA (that has an easement for this path) to address the drainage issues.

Project Title: Traffic light-corner of Field & Fern; School crossing guard- Concord & Fern
Project Description: These are two very dangerous corners for kids, pedestrians, bikers and car drivers.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: A Raised Intersection At Trowbridge and Harvard
Project Description: Car drive too fast on Trowbridge Street. Installing a raised intersection would calm traffic and promote better pedestrian crossings for this important school route.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: A wayfinding assessment and street, lighting, and public art solution to a dangerous intersection
Project Description: The intersection at Inman Square is extremely dangerous for bikers, pedestrians, and cars.  We need a holistic solution that improves the safety of the intersection and enhances the attractiveness of the area.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. Inman Square traffic study to improve the area will begin in spring 2015.

Project Title: Crosswalk on White Street between the Porter Square Galleria  and Shopping Center parking lots.
Project Description: A crosswalk would make it safer to cross the street here when there is a lot of traffic turning into and out of the parking lots from White Street. It might encourage foot traffic to the Porter Square Galleria shops.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.
Entities: Crosswalk,White Street,parking lots,Porter Square Galleria,Shopping Center

Project Title: Crosswalk warning lights embedded in the road on Mass. Ave at the intersection of Garfield Street.
Project Description: This intersection is used by students, shoppers, and walkers, and runners to connect across Mass. Ave. in a district with shopping, restaurants, and bus stops. It's a large 4 lane crosswalk area between two sets of traffic lights. Drivers often ignore or don't see pedestrians in this crosswalk because they are looking ahead to the next set of traffic lights. A system with embedded lights would help signal simultaneously to the 4 lanes of traffic that someone is waiting to cross the road. Crossing the road is currently a game of leapfrog from one lane to the next. One lane of traffic might stop but the other lane, going in the same direction, might not stop. It also feels unsafe to cross 2 lanes and then wait at the small median in order to cross the second set of 2 lanes while traffic on both sides rushes past.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. A flashing signal that can be activated by pedestrians is being installed on Mass. Ave. at Garfield Street as part of the ongoing street and sidewalk construction.

Project Title: Crosswalk warning sign at corner of Vassal Lane and Fresh Pond Pkwy
Project Description: Drivers entering Fresh Pond Parkway from Lake View Ave / Vassal Lane are often so focused on oncoming traffic that they fail to notice the pedestrian crosswalk on FPP.  By placing a "WARNING -- CROSSWALK" sign just below the STOP sign at the intersection, drivers will be reminded to look both ways before accelerating into the traffic on FPP.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.
Entities: Crosswalk warning sign,corner,Vassal Lane,Fresh Pond Pkwy

Project Title: Curb extension at Cambridge and Line Street
Project Description: The crosswalk is long, the right turn is fast and the pedestrian/vehicle sight line is terrible when there is a vehicle parked at the corner (metered parking here). There are a lot of pedestrians crossing here, including many elderly and caretakers with young children who are going to Cambridge Hospital. Please consider adding a curb extension at this location.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Dedicated left turn lanes/signals with correctly timed walk signals in Inman Square
Project Description: Safety for pedestrians and motorists.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. Inman Square traffic study to improve the area will begin in spring 2015.

Project Title: Diagonal crosswalks
Project Description: Lots of pedestrians here, rather than waiting twice you could cross diagonally.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Fix sidewalks in North Cambridge from St. John's church to Arlington line
Project Description: I was walking with my parents who are elderly and my mother fell because she was unable to see all the bumps in the sidewalk.  It's becoming dangerous.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Fix the heave in brick sidewalk on corner of Mass Ave & Western Ave by H&R Block
Project Description: I tripped on this while running to catch the light (and a particular train so I could catch a bus) and sprained my arm and foot. Someone could easily get hurt again. The ridge runs parallel to Mass Ave. about 6 ft from the curb cut on Mass Ave between Western Ave. and the inbound T stairway.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.
Entities: heave,brick sidewalk,corner,Mass Ave & Western Ave,H&R Block

Project Title: Fixing Inman Square crosswalk lights & park seating
Project Description:
Crossing the street in Inman Square is unsafe. Drivers do not believe pedestrians are seeking a walk signal because of the poor design and timing. I have seen many fights, even with elderly pedestians. Unsafe and shameful. But, easy and cost-free to fix. Simply copy timing system of Union Square where ALL TRAFFIC STOPS and all pedestrians see a walk signal during each light cycle.  Simple.

The summer shaded seating at the Valucci Memorial Tribute Park in Inman Square has been blocked for 3 or 4 years now by the bike rental station. In the hot summer, only seating under the sun is open.  Poor design by people who do not live near this park.  Easy and cost-free to fix.  Either pushout the bike rental station 2 feet away from the shaded seating (give a 2 foot space between the seating and bike station), or move the bike rental station to the hot sun-drenched side of the park.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. Inman Square traffic study to improve the area will begin in spring 2015.

Project Title: Fixing the holes in the street in Inman Square
Project Description: I ride my bike and there are lots of holes in the street, especially on Beacon Street
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. Inman Square traffic study to improve the area will begin in spring 2015. The Community Development Department advises that Beacon Street is in Somerville.

Project Title: Heating the sidewalk by solar-powered underground wires
Project Description: It would melt the snow, make the sidewalks less slippery in winter, and cause less salt and chemicals to seep into the ground.  Japan does this - Cambridge should do the same.
Project Status: Not eligible - too expensive.

Project Title: Hire teens to shovel snow at pedestrian intersections and catch basins at the Inman Sq. intersection
Project Description: public safety
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds.

Project Title: Improve safety for those crossing at the Brattle/Craigie/Sparks Street intersection
Project Description: This intersection has quickly-moving traffic on a curved section of Brattle with traffic from Sparks and Craigie also entering. Something needs to be done to smooth vehicular traffic during rush hours, but for now this proposal focuses on pedestrian safety while crossing Brattle and also the mouth of lower Sparks Street (drivers often fly off of Brattle onto Sparks without seeing pedestrians because of the angle of the road's curve). I would like the city to study the intersection and install some pedestrian signals that clearly stop traffic in all directions if deemed appropriate.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Install a large sign that identifies "Inman Square" at the Camb/Spring/Beacon intersection
Project Description: Visitors, restaurant patrons
Project Status: An idea to place wayfinding banners to identify neighborhoods and commercial districts around the city made it to the ballot, but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Install flashing yellow lights at the intersection between Mass Ave & Garden St before Dawes Island
Project Description: This intersection right before Harvard Square off of the Cambridge Common park is very dangerous. This is a tricky area for drivers who, especially those who don't know the area, aren't always aware they need to slow down before taking the right onto MA ave. This is a highly trafficked area by walkers, bikers, and cars alike.
Project Status: Budget Delegates felt that this is a traffic timing issue and shared the idea with the Traffic Department.

Project Title: Install pedestrian push button signal at crosswalk in front of BBN school.
Project Description: it will reduce frustration for both pedestrians and drivers stemming from the current, poorly timed traffic signal.
Project Status: Budget Delegates discussed this idea at length, but felt that it is a traffic timing issue. The idea was shared with the  Traffic Department, who advised that this is state property, not City property.

Project Title: Traffic Garden
Project Description: it can educate children about biking, traffic, pedestrian safety, and bike skills
Project Status: This project made it to the ballot, but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Install sidewalks at this busy location!
Project Description: This heavily traveled section of Huron Avenue is completely without a sidewalk, forcing people to walk in the street or cross 4 lanes of traffic to use the sidewalk on the opposite side of Huron Avenue. Please complete the sidewalk work begun previously and provide a safe path to Glacken Field, the Haggerty School, and beyond.
Project Status: This was a high priority project for Budget Delegates, but the project cost was estimated at over $500,000.

Project Title: Install speed bumps at the slope near the bottom of Fayerweather Street near Huron Ave.
Project Description: Fayerweather Street is a major cut-through for cars trying to avoid Fresh Pond Parkway traffic. As the street slopes down, cars really pick up speed. We have quite a lot of children in the area (including a toddler and one on the way) and it is quite hair-raising to watch cars, often work pick-up trucks, go flying up and down the street. Particularly since it has been re-paved due to local construction, cars are treating it like a highway.
Project Status: The Community Development Department advises that Fayerweather Street on either side of Huron Avenue is scheduled to be rebuilt. A design has been completed for the intersection with Huron and it includes a modified raised crosswalk to slow vehicles approaching the crosswalk.

Project Title: Install underground utility wires
Project Description: This project could be done citywide. We could have our own utility company install wires underground. It would help Cambridge residents keep their electricity when there is a bad storm. It could maybe be done in phases.
Project Status: Not eligible - too expensive.

Project Title: Integrate Fern Street streetscape improvements (pavement, signage, lighting, green...) with the new-
Project Description: Safe, clear and inviting connection between school, playground and Danhy park.
Project Status: This suggestion is already underway as part of the current sewer separation project.

Project Title: Linear Park
Project Description: Add wastebaskets between Cameron Ave. and where Somerville begins - they have plenty!
Project Status: Budget Delegates researched this idea, but decided that the area wasn't wide enough to accommodate trash cans.  The idea was shared with the City's Open Space Committee, which is looking into upgrades for Linear Park.

Project Title: Make a travel lane for ambulances/fire trucks/public safety/health
Project Description: where most needed
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Make the intersection around Cambridge Boat Club pedestrian friendly
Project Description: Currently coming down from Fresh Pond to the Charles River is a nightmare. The intersection just before the river around the boat club is nearly impassable on foot. Proper intersections, lights and crosswalks are needed.
Project Status: This idea was shared with the Traffic Department, but it's not eligible since it's not City property (belongs to state).

Project Title: Make traffic flow better where Cambridge St. & Hampshire St and Beacon St. intersect.
Project Description: This is a clogged and confusing intersection where drivers all have different ideas of the rules if the road. There needs to be clearer traffic flow. 1) Going east on Cambridge Street at the light at Inman st. :the left lane should be only for cars going ahead to Cambridge Street and those turning left onto Springfield. The right lane should be only for those cars going to Hampshire and turning left. 2) For those going east on Beacon st. to Cambridge St. and those going west on Hampshire to Beacon: there needs to be a way to get drivers to pull up enough to turn BEHIND the ongoing cars that are stopped & waiting to turn (rather than pulling in front and blocking the flow) either signs or makings like a little rotary might encourage this.
Project Status: Budget Delegates felt that this is a traffic timing issue and shared the idea with the Traffic Department. Inman Square traffic study to improve the area will begin in spring 2015.
Entities: traffic flow,Cambridge St. & Hampshire St,Beacon St.

Project Title: Pedestrian Priority Traffic Signals
Project Description: Cars drive too fast on Trowbridge Street and there are long wait times for children going to school and residents walking. Let's change these signals into ones where the pedestrian controls the timing.
Project Status: Budget Delegates felt that this is a traffic timing issue and shared the idea with the Traffic Department.

Project Title: Phone calls for street cleaning both days each month
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds. Public Works advises that residents can sign up through E-line to receive information about street cleaning through text message or email.

Project Title: More parking for Inman Square residents
Project Description: I have lived here for several years and with all the area "visitors" there is a terrible strain on parking, more so than many other Cambridge areas. The city lot on Springfield street could be made more accessible to locals. Changing the metered time to 9:00AM-7:00PM would be beneficial to residents who avoid the lot due to the current time restriction which result in tickets early in the morning and late in the evening.
Project Status: Not eligible - not a capital idea. This idea was shared with the Traffic Department, who advised that this area will be part of 8am-to-8pm meter implementation.

Project Title: Replace current traffic lights with smart traffic signals to reduce vehicle emissions.
Project Description: This would improve the flow of cars by automatically adjusting traffic based on the need of the intersection at a particular time of day. It would reduce the amount of idling cars, traffic congestion and vehicle emissions. It would help increase the flow and speed of bus  transportation for areas not served by the T. In a recent test of this technology done between Carnegie Mellon and Pittsburg PA it was determined that "time spent stopped at the lights was reduced by 40 percent, and overall travel time was also decreased by 26 percent. This marked drop in wait time and decrease of wasted fossil fuels had a projected 21 percent reduction in the motor vehicular emissions that were tested". This is an environmental proposal that will help contribute to a more livable city.
Project Status: Budget Delegates felt that this is a traffic timing issue and shared the idea with the Traffic Department.

Project Title: Provide vastly better road signage starting with the major roads
Project Description: Cambridge, like most Massachusetts cities, has extremely poor road signage, even on major streets.  The problem is especially acute because of our large number of senior citizens, and newcomers who move here each year. Poor signage leads to accidents, hair pulling frustration, late appointments, and increased pollution.  Given these experiences, many citizens conclude that Government can't do anything right, and vote accordingly. Cambridge should make its signage serviceable for local and regional drivers.
Project Status: An idea to place wayfinding banners to identify neighborhoods and commercial districts around the city made it to the ballot, but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Put in a traffic light at Ellery and Broadway
Project Description: traffic safety for cars and pedestrians, cars frequently do not give the proper right of way and I have nearly been hit crossing to the library
Project Status: Given that there is a traffic light at Trowbridge and Broadway, Budget Delegates did not feel that having another light at Ellery and Broadway was a high priority project.

Project Title: Add stop sign for traffic on Banks Street
Project Description: This intersection is very dangerous for pedestrians and cyclists. The stop sign on Cowperthwaite street is on the left hand side and often missed by drivers, and on the right is a tall brick wall that obstructs drivers' view to Banks Street. If you are on a bike lawfully riding up Cowperthwaite, picking up speed to make it up the hill on Surrey, then you suddenly emerge from behind a wall to drivers zipping up Banks.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. They shared the idea with the Traffic Department.

Project Title: Create Better Public Space
Project Description: This intersection is difficult for drivers, pedestrians, buses, and cyclists. Let's remake the whole thing that serves the public better, calms traffic, and creates more usable space!
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. They shared the idea with the Traffic Department.

Project Title: Address dangerous intersection at Fresh Pond Parkway and Huron Ave
Project Description:
Pedestrians at risk due to speeding, inattentive drivers, poor signal timing, and lack of signage.
I would like to point out an easily addressed aspect of the dangerous intersection of Fresh Pond Parkway and Huron Avenue.
This crossing is the site of at least one pedestrian fatality that I know of. 
We need "a no right turn on red" here. 

At present Westbound( toward the Charles River) traffic is permitted to turn right on red, despite the fact that the pedestrian crossing sign says "go."
The slope and configuration of this intersection for some reason encourages drivers to treat it as a speed way, resulting in dangerous behavior when turning right from the Parkway onto Huron Ave. 
Drivers may or may not actually stop before turning right on red, but few look at the cross walk they are about to speed through. 
There are many close calls every hour. Close calls are precursors to catastrophe, but they do not appear in the city data.
Project Status: Not eligible - not City property (belongs to state).

Project Title: Arrange parking with commercial lots during snow and street cleaning
Project Status: Not eligible - would require operating funds.

Project Title: More ways for residents to access the beautiful spaces we have on the Charles River
Project Description: whether overpasses, pedestrian lights, etc.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Shelters for school crossing guards.  Fletcher Maynard Academy, Windsor/Broadway and all schools.
Project Description: Crossing guards stand outside in the weather for an hour in the morning and two hours in the afternoon to safely cross Cambridge students to schools and buses.  During bad weather crossing guards would benefit by being able to warm up or not have to stand in pouring rain during wait times when they are not guiding students across the street.  The shelters could be portable and foldable so they could be stored in the school building; or perhaps in a business if the crossing guard works on the route but not right outside the school.  A Boy Scout in South Dakota built a model for crossing guards so it can be done!
Project Status: Budget Delegates recommended this project for the ballot, but the City advised that the proposed location was not wide enough to accommodate shelters without obstructing driver and pedestrian views or hindering sidewalk accessibility.

Project Title: Traffic Garden
Project Description:
The younger generation is more obese than ever and many studies point to the lack of active transportation in their lives.  To inspire independence in our children and teach them to navigate our streets by biking and walking, the Dutch present a proven model called the Traffic Garden.  "The school curriculum includes regular field trips to the local 'traffic garden.' The City of Utrecht has used this facility, a streetscape in miniature, to teach kids the rules of the road since the 1950s. Students take turns as cyclists, pedestrians and car drivers, learning how to take other types of street users into consideration. The hands-on experience navigating the traffic garden gives kids the skills and confidence to get around the city under their own power as soon as their early teens" (http://vimeo.com/31545084).

We need a game changer for our health, environment, education and community and the traffic garden checks all the boxes.
Project Status: This project made it to the ballot, but did not receive enough votes to win funding.

Project Title: Remove the meters and create community space on city lot #6, moveable chairs/tables
Project Description: We need to create community space for people, not cars. Remove meters, create a space with moveable chairs and tables for music, craft fairs, dance parties, social events, if enough money put a transparent roof on it.
Project Status: Budget Delegates felt that removing parking in Cambridge is a very touchy subject and were not prepared to take it on this time around.

Project Title: Remove the parking meters and create a community space in lot #4 with moveable tables and chairs and
Project Description: Create a community space rather than parking on city lot 4 on Essex and Bishop Allen Drive with moveable tables and chairs with a possible covering for music, crafts, gatherings, dances, eating etc. We lack community spaces!
Project Status: Budget Delegates felt that removing parking in Cambridge is a very touchy subject and were not prepared to take it on this time around.

Project Title: Remove the parking meters on city lot #5 and replace it with a smooth surface, with moveable chairs,
Project Description: We need a common square to help build community, keeping space for the farmers market, craft fairs, etc.
Project Status: Budget Delegates felt that removing parking in Cambridge is a very touchy subject and were not prepared to take it on this time around.

Project Title: Restore Parkland by Removing Redundant Lanes
Project Description: This road functions too much like a highway running through the heart of our fair city. Let's calm and reduce traffic by reducing the amount of lanes to no more than 2 each direction. We can bring back parkland and improve bike/ped connections to the river and ponds.
Project Status: Not eligible - not City property (belongs to state).

Project Title: Create city-wide congestion pricing during weekdays
Project Description: Cambridge is an employment center but even though we have good transit service and bike facilities, too many out of town workers drive into the city burdening us to with traffic, pollution, and parking. Instigating congestion pricing at city lines during peak hours would raise much needed funds for community centers and schools, while lowering taxes, traffic, and pollution across the city. Central London--roughly the same size as Cambridge--did this and brought in millions, and made all traffic flow much smoother.
Project Status: Not eligible - not a capital project.

Project Title: attach a special fee to parking permits for all parking meters
Project Description: to not have to search for coins. [Further explanation via email: We pay $20.00 for a parking permit for Cambridge. Would it be possible to put an option on the parking permit when purchasing, if you would like for an extra fee per year a sticker put on the parking permit that allows you to park at meters without paying the machine,  The rules would still apply such as 2 hours at a time, but we wouldn't have to fee the meter personally,  Meter People would have to keep an eye on the timing,]
Project Status: Not eligible - not a capital project.

Project Title: Fix Norfolk Street Parking Lot
Project Description: While the City generously gifted the residents of Norfolk Street a parking lot, it is badly in need of maintenance and order.  There are large deep potholes that residents have tried to fix with bags of cement, but at this point, it has gotten pretty treacherous.  Also, there are no lines painted for the parking spaces, so the lot becomes a game of Tetris with people blocking each other in as they attempt to squeeze into the lot.  A bit of repair and a bit of order would make the parking lot safer, cleaner and more neighborly.
Project Status: Several Budget Delegates searched for this parking lot, but could not find a City-owned parking lot on Norfolk Street in disrepair.

Project Title: Free public parking lot near Central Square and the Community Learning Center
Project Description: I have to pick my children up from school in this area, but it's very hard for me to find a space.  Even though I have a parking permit all of the spots are usually full.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project, because there are already City-owned parking lots in the area on Bishop Allen Drive. A new parking lot would be too expensive (because of land acquisition costs).

Project Title: More parking in Central Square
Project Description: There are no spaces
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project, because there are already City-owned parking lots in the area on Bishop Allen Drive.

Project Title: More parking in the Fresh Pond area
Project Description: More parking is important
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: More public off-street parking off Cambridge Street or Hampshire
Project Description: between Inman Square and East Cambridge
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Move the no standing zone two or three car lengths away from the corner of Broadway and Elm on the N
Project Description: This would return the no standing zone back to what it was before the new sidewalks, then cars would not have to block the crosswalk to see oncoming cars making it safer for children going to the Cambridgeport School and community playground
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Move the six metered parking spaces on Mass Ave/Harvard Square which led to pushing back bus berths
Project Description:
Re-establish better "connectivity" for #1 & #69 Bus passengers, both to and 
from Harvard Square T Station, and general area Harvard Square.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Add more lighting over the Harvard Plaza, it's much too dark at night, not safe!
Project Description: Safety for pedestrians and bicyclists.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Improve area around Foundry Building
Project Description: This area is secluded and dark.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Install more lights throughout North Cambridge
Project Description: Some streets are too dark and it is dangerous for residents.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Install more street lights on Hancock Street between Harvard and Central.
Project Description: It is too dark on the streets and is dangerous for residents.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Lighting at park at tri corner of magazine and green st and mass ave
Project Description: Lighting is needed for safety issues in this area especially after the sun goes down
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Lighting for dark areas, interactive sculptures, and hang out spaces to encourage safety at night
Project Description: Installing lighting in dark areas, interactive sculptures, and designating "hang out" spaces in places like Kendall Square, Central Square past Brookline Street, and near bus stops would help people feel more safe in the evening, especially those that are walking around the City at that time.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: lights for pathways that are very dark
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Lights to Keep Cars Off Commuter Rail Tracks
Project Description: Last week a car was stuck on the commuter rail tracks where the cross Sherman St. This was not the first time a driver at night thought they were turning into the Jose's Mexican Restaurant parking lot. In the two incidents that I know about, the other one was in 2013, no one was hurt. But the cars were totaled and there were I'm sure significant Cambridge police and fire department expenses. Could lights that illuminate the tracks at Sherman Street or at least a couple of "Do Not Enter" signs be placed beside the tracks?
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Living Light: On Rindge Ave., Sherman St., and all of Cambridge, there a number of cross walks that
Project Description: I leave for work early and come home late and have a  very hard time seeing runners and walkers at the cross walk.  If I'm young and healthy then I'm sure this is for others.  I feel terrible when I've missed a person trying to walk, run, or I have to stop short and scare them.  Using solar power could save money and be something a lot of urban areas could implement to allow for safe crossing.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Night lighting for the CHarles Sumner statue in conjunction with the public toilet project.
Project Description: It highlights an important public monument in a highly visible location.  The lighting should be energy-efficient and designed in conjunction with the new public toilet project.  It will provide evening wayfinding for the facilities users.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Street lighting improvements
Project Description: Streets are poorly lit in Area 4: Cherry, Pine, Washington, Suffolk, Worchester, Windsor streets
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To fix the street lights.
Project Description: it is dark and unsafe, especially by train tracks.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: More multilingual signgs
Project Description: for example, about elections.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: A process for not making things worse
Project Description: A walking tour of this neighborhood is one of pointing out where changes have made things needlessly worse. Renovations of city parks & property most always result in making public use more burdensome. This is because the neighborhood residents always the ones to actually use the public sidewalks or park have no meaningful say in the changes. New sidewalk setbacks do look mighty nice while looking out from a city car, but for the local neighborhood people commuting by foot every day, they have lost the awnings overhead which had provided shelter from rain.  They have lost close abutting wallfronts which had provided to all on the sidewalks shade from the blazing summer sun.  Inside the parks, utility and functionality is needlessly lost, but, hey, new designs from the high paid office expert all look mighty nice looking from afar while driving by in a city truck or car.  To stop changes from making things worse, a neighborhood person who actually uses the public space should be sought.
Project Status: Not eligible - not a capital project. This idea was shared with the Community Development Department.

Project Title: Wi-Fi in more youth centers (Area IV, Gately, Russell, Moore, Frisoli)
Project Description: Kids play on their phones a lot and Wi-Fi is needed
Project Status: There is already wifi in all five Youth Centers, and a winning PB project from last year will expand outdoor wifi coverage near four of the Youth Centers.

Project Title: Building permit process:independent neighbor person must agree that paperwork matches real life
Project Description:
A store shut down and some red "C" permit papers were placed in the windows. Grid-like framing of 2"X4" studs were attached to the exterior of the old existing facade, and then added onto the 2"X4" studs was a new wood facade. This resulted in the front of the store pushing out 5 inches. In other words, the sidewalk became 5 inches narrower and it is now the narrowest section of sidewalk on the block which has elderly housing with wheelchairs. The windows now sit deep in the swollen thick facade. The building inspector for this area of Cambridge won employee of the year. Either the owner had special permission to build out into the sidewalk unlike any other building on the block (hard to believe), or the builder did this expansion with the city building inspector having no clue. 
The way to fix the building permit process is to include an independent neighbor person who must sign and agree that construction paperwork approved by the city matches what really happens in real life.
Project Status: Not eligible - not a capital project. This idea was shared with Inspectional Services.

Project Title: Citywide free Wi-Fi
Project Description: If too expensive, start with low income areas especially "projects"
Project Status: Although Budget Delegates ranked this as high need and impact project, it's not possible to provide free citywide wifi coverage with the $600,000 available for PB.  A project to add free wifi to Lopez, Raymond, and Dana Parks made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: Free Wi-Fi throughout Cambridge
Project Description: We're one of two major technology hubs in the US, yet we don't have decent free access throughout Cambridge?  This seems absurd.
Project Status: Although Budget Delegates ranked this as high need and impact project, it's not possible to provide free citywide wifi coverage with the $600,000 available for PB.  A project to add free wifi to Lopez, Raymond, and Dana Parks made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: To provide Wi-Fi at Cambridge train stations
Project Description: It would provide internet access at stations in Cambridge.
Project Status: Not eligible: the City does not have jurisdiction over MBTA property.

Project Title: Free Wi-Fi In CHA Properties during extensive construction activities 2015-2016
Project Description: As we remodel our communities people, especially in CHA properties, the space formerly dedicated to playgrounds for the children in Newtowne Court is currently occupied with dumpsters and other heavy construction equipment. Thus the children are confined indoors and could benefit as school starts with access to the internet to keep themselves busy with academic activities and relaxing games online.
Project Status: Not eligible: the City does not have jurisdiction over CHA property.

Project Title: I think we should continue expanding Wi-Fi access - specifically to the public housing buildings
Project Description: So much of our lives are moving to the web and it becomes a serious disadvantage both for work and school if you do not have reliable and affordable access.
Project Status: Not eligible: the City does not have jurisdiction over CHA property.

Project Title: Free public internet for all C.H.A properties
Project Description: Free Public internet for all C.H.A properties. The Current free wifi in Newtowne Court is hard to access from with in your apartment. We need a stronger wifi signal or some thing that allows you to access the free wifi with out having to be outside.  Children in CPS need internet access and should not have to rely only on Comcast.
Project Status: Not eligible: the City does not have jurisdiction over CHA property.

Project Title: Better Wi-Fi service for public housing
Project Description: Internet signal should be stronger. Tired of going outside to use it.
Project Status: Not eligible: the City does not have jurisdiction over CHA property.

Project Title: Expand the accessibility of free Wi-fi to public parks
Project Description: In nice days, people spend more time outdoors and people like to stay connected.  At the same time, people get to meet their neighbors.
Project Status: A project to add free wifi to Lopez, Raymond, and Dana Parks made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: To provide Wi-Fi at all schools and public parks
Project Description: This would provide internet accessibility at all public locations throughout the city. Many of these areas do not have wi-fi access.
Project Status: All Cambridge Public Schools have free wifi.  A project to add free wifi to Lopez, Raymond, and Dana Parks made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: FIBER OPTIC INTERNET!!
Project Description: Given our historic nature, unfortunately some technologies have left us in the dust. Our only broadband provider has a monopoly and is sloooow, due to aging copper-wire infrastructure. Although Harvard University has incredible internet, the same can't be said about the neighborhoods around the rest of Cambridge. I moved from a neighborhood to campus solely because the internet was so much more superior. Unreliable, slow internet is not a great representative of a forward-thinking community such as ours. I lived in the South Boston, where AT&T provides awesome fiber optic internet for relatively good rates, the same as I was paying for crappy cable. We should either encourage the current company to step up their game, or invite AT&T to bring their fiber optics here. We should also apply to be the next Google Fiber city, if we haven't already done so. TLDR: fast internet can make all the difference in how a community progresses. Get fiber here now, and stop relying on 1800's technology
Project Status: Not eligible. Fiber optic internet infrastucture already exists in Cambridge. Fiber optic internet is available through Verizon. AT&T does not provide internet in Cambridge, but encouraging that company to come here is not a capital project.

Project Title: To bring Verizon FIOS to Cambridge
Project Description: it would allow choices and hopefully lower costs for residents.
Project Status: Not eligible. Verizon FIOS is already available in Cambridge. This is not a capital project.

Project Title: More outlets at charging stations or have more stations
Project Description: There aren't enough at current charging stations. They should be Citywide
Project Status: A project to add 10 more Soofa benches around Cambridge made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: More charger benches - near more parks, Columbia St, & near Izzy's
Project Description: Sometimes people are unable to go home to charge phones.
Project Status: A project to add 10 more Soofa benches around Cambridge made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: MORE SOOFA BENCHES!
Project Description: A free place to charge - this is great. Plus they look amazing and cool!
Project Status: A project to add 10 more Soofa benches around Cambridge made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: Solar / PVC charging stations for subway stations
Project Description: Our subway stations are spaces with limited use and function.  To create better spaces for subway stations, install solar / pvc charging stations for passengers waiting for trains across all Cambridge red line stations.
Project Status: Not eligible: the City does not have jurisdiction over MBTA property.

Project Title: Add solar charging stations for phone in public parks
Project Description: People need to use their phones in emergencies
Project Status: A project to add 10 more Soofa benches around Cambridge made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: To provide more solar benches at parks & next to bus stops
Project Description: The soofa benches have been very popular and more should be placed at parks and near bus stops.
Project Status: A project to add 10 more Soofa benches around Cambridge made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: Install digital signs at various locations throughout the city indicating what's happening in Cambridge
Project Description: Install digital signs at various locations throughout the city indicating what's happening in Cambridge, similar to the signs in front of city hall. However, these signs can be automatically changed/updated through the Find It Cambridge website (www.finditcambridge.org) which will be launched in early 2016. The website will be a tool to find activities, services, and resources that are available for children, youth and families in Cambridge. The signs will enable more residents to find out what is happening in Cambridge in real time.
Project Status: A project to install a digital sign in front of City Hall made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: New carpet for children's room in Main Library
Project Description: Please replace the carpet in the 3rd floor children's room in the Main Library.  Babies crawl on the carpet but it's not very clean.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high need or high impact project compared to other ideas.

Project Title: Redesign of city websites (in particular for permit submissions)
Project Description: The permit website (ex. for moving van permits) is a complete joke that looks like it was designed by a three year old. It has an absurdly unfriendly user interface and apparently rejects form submissions from most modern browsers, wasting everybody's time.  The city which boasts MIT shouldn't suffer from technological ineptitude.  I propose we hire a few college kids to spend a week bringing the city's web site into the 21st century.
Project Status: This project is already included in the City's FY16 capital plan and the website redesign is currently underway.

Project Title: To redesign the city's website to make it more user friendly
Project Description: This should be an infrastructure improvement priority.  It frustrates users, esp. when you need the info quickly.
Project Status: This project is already included in the City's FY16 capital plan and the website redesign is currently underway.

Project Title: Mobile City Residents Issue Reporting/Tracking System
Project Description: We (local entrepreneurs in Cambridge) have built a mobile application (Mobile City Residents Issue Reporting/Tracking System) that will allow Cambridge residents to report issues, feedback and suggestions directly to the concerned official and department quickly and in a cost effective manner.  In this project, signs containing a two dimensional barcode will be posted at various locations in the city. People can use their smartphone to scan (or enter a short url code in their browser) and access a site and choose from multiple categories, and report problems or suggestions. They can take photographs of the site and attach to their complaint. The message will go directly to the concerned department and alert emails can be sent to multiple people within the city administration to track and report the progress of the resolution. The person reporting the problem will receive confirmation of the progress of the resolution. [Project description continued in comments]
Project Status: The City already uses a mobile application called Commonwealth Connect (iReport was previously used) to receive, track, and respond to resident reports of issues and requests for services.

Project Title: To build an app that details all local events occuring and upcoming
Project Description: This would make sure that residents are aware of local events. The app could detail events based upon what is suitable for various ages such as teens, adults etc.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high need or high impact project compared to other ideas.

Project Title: Create an app that will keep residents abreast of current secular mindfulness events in Cambridge
Project Description: There is a growing interest in mindfulness amongst parents,  students & families in Cambridge. More schools and health centers are offering mindfulness instruction to reduce stress, increase learning & resilience. There are a lot of events happening in Cambridge that parents and students hear about, but we need a more centralized way to distribute this information so people can grow their skills as individuals and as a community.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high need or high impact project compared to other ideas.  They suggested that these events be added to existing weekly emails to listervs.

Project Title: More multilingual signs citywide
Project Description: for example, about elections
Project Status: A project to install a digital sign in front of City Hall that would display information in multiple languages made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: More community bulletin boards
Project Description: Like in Porter Square. more local. Could include city notices (upcoming events, festivals, social services, elections, etc.) in multiple languages
