If CPD Officers and community leaders were funded to train and play Strategies for Youth's Juvenile Justice Jeopardy at community centers and at the Cambridge Police Department, youth would be exposed to accurate information about these issues. The game would also foster positive relationships among officers and the Cambridge youth they serve and protect. This will be especially beneficial for youth who have had negative interactions with police. The game will improve Cambridge community spirit, and will help youth stop and consider their actions before engaging in risky behavior that may jeopardize their future. The game could be played consistently and would be periodically updated. The game would be based on MA law, Cambridge arrest data, and local school codes of conduct.  Cost: $10,000.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project, because the Cambridge Police Department already offers this time of program.

Project Title: More community policing
Project Description: on the street walking in neighborhoods, especially in dangerous areas. More interaction with the community, including meetings.  The first reaction to seeing please should not be being scared.
Project Status: Not eligible: not a capital project (requires significant operating expenses).

Project Title: Increase the safety of police officers and the communities in which they serve by using neuroscience
Project Description: There is a recent discovery made at MIT that the company SplitSage (based in Cambridge) is using that can identify blind spots in people's line of sight. With the increase of tension in communities, shouldn't we know where officers have blind spots to better allow them to protect not only themselves but the people here in Cambridge as well?
Project Status: Not eligible: not a capital project.

Project Title: Provide police communication 2 way radios to all school and related crossing guards
Project Description: Crossing guards have no employer provided communication tools to report accidents, safety concerns and urgent/emergent needs.  Currently, they do not have the ability to receive Amber alerts and other community emergency announcements.  Cambridge needs to be able to rely on crossing guards to provide timely safety communication to first responders as well as providing them a means to assure their own safety.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Advertise the iReport Cambridge App
Project Description: This almost free suggestion could make our community more awesome. Graffiti is everywhere in Cambridge, and relatively few people know they can make an impact by simply reporting it on this app. The simply take a photo and upload it. However, people won't know what to do if they don't know this app exists. The app should be advertised on banners across the most heavily populated areas, and most heavily graffitied. Central Square, I'm looking at you. Also, the app should be made more like the Boston 311 app, which works very well. The photo can be taken and uploaded later, when convenient, as the map information is taken from the photo, not where you're at. Most importantly, Boston responds very quickly and resolves issues fast. Citizens have to know that their voice makes a difference. Let's try to beautify our city, and make it look less like 1970's Bronx.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To provide security systems for CHA apartments
Project Description: This would provide an extra layer of security for apartments that are a part of CHA.
Project Status: Not eligible: not City property.

Project Title: Install security cameras on the outside of all public buildings
Project Description: to increase safety
Project Status: Given the amount of public concerns about security cameras and privacy issues, the City declined to move this idea forward through PB. The issue would need to be handled through the City Council.

Project Title: Install security cameras at Franklin Street Park
Project Description: To make the park a safe public park for all visitors. Installing security cameras would prevent users from smoking certain things in the park and/or reduce troublesome behaviors like teenagers climbing trees.
Project Status: Given the amount of public concerns about security cameras and privacy issues, the City declined to move this idea forward through PB. The issue would need to be handled through the City Council.

Project Title: Make the area near Walden Street and Porter Square safer
Project Description: by adding more lighting, security cameras, and police patrols, if possible.  Two students reported witnessing or experiencing attacks in that area and don't feel safe walking there at night.
Project Status: Given the amount of public concerns about security cameras and privacy issues, the City declined to move security camera issues forward through PB. They would instead need to be handled through the City Council.  Adding police patrols would require operating funds, not capital funds.

Project Title: Lighted Path at Danehy and/or between St. Peter's Field
Project Description: The path between Danehy Park and St. Peter's Field is very dark. With Danehy being a very popular park and a frequently traveled one, it makes sense to have it well lit at night. There are plenty of families that would enjoy walking at night if the park were properly lit. Biking home through that area at night is always met with complete darkness.  The other area of Danehy that could use light is the path area by the dog park. In other words, Danehy Park should be well lit at night. It is a huge connector to the Fresh Pond for all of those traveling by foot, by bike, etc. from Garden Street, Walden St, and Huron. I have seen people walk from Trader Joe's and through the park at night. Wouldn't they like some light?
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: More lighting after dark in parks
Project Description: There needs to be more lighting in parks for safety.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Lights at Danehy Dog Park
Project Description: Safety for dogs and owners who can only arrive after work when little natural light remains especially in winter.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Improve the lighting near the small park near the Porter Square T Station
Project Description: In bad weather and in the evening it can feel somewhat threatening because it is hard to see who is in there.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Increased Lighting in Clement G. Morgan Park Area
Project Description: We need better, more efficient lighting in the park so that we can see more clearly as we walk through in the later evening hours. Installing LED street lights would allow us to move through the space far more confidently.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Add lights to swings at Russell Field
Project Description: When it gets dark we can't see if there aren't any lights
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To provide more lighting at basketball courts
Project Description: This would allow people to play basketball later in the evening with adequate lighting.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Street lights on the Fitchburg Cutoff Path
Project Description: Street lights will make it safer for bikers and walkers that take this path from Belmont to Alewife, especially in the winter months when it is dark for both the morning and evening commutes.  They should be on sensors, so that as people walk/bike toward them they go on, then go off again after a set amount of time (5 minutes?)
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To add lighting to sidewalks
Project Description: There are many side streets that are extremely dark. This would provide security as well as visibility. So, that pedestrians can safely walk throughout the city.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: A planted island at either end of Mass Ave, one at Upland Rd and one at Waterhouse Square.
Project Description: The islands would clearly separate travel lanes, mark and beautify the two ends of this historic section of Mass Ave, and bring calm to a very busy, noisy, complicated part of the city.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. The City considered this, but there's no room in the Porter Square area.

Project Title: One more bench per block on each side of Mass ave from Lafayette square to the Post Office & City Hall
Project Description: Lots of people who find walking challenging for a variety of reasons would be able to do more walking for errands if they could sit and rest more frequently. (I have heard many people say this. I got the idea from them)
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project, because many blocks already have benches.

Project Title: To provide a road test car at the high school
Project Description: For many residents there is a need for a suitable road test car to be able to take the road test for their license. This would be a great resource for Cambridge residents, especially those that utilize the driver's ed program at the high school.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To host a bike safety day where free bike helmets could be distributed
Project Description: Cambridge has promoted more bike usage but hasn't done a good job with bike safety. This idea would allow free bike helmets and even possibly lights to be distributed & general bike safety discussed.
Project Status: Not eligible: not a capital project.

Project Title: To place more defibrillators in city buildings
Project Description: There has been expanded training for use of defibrillators. But there are not enough placed in city buildings. These devices could save a life and more should be made available.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project, because there are already 25 defibrillatots in City Fire Department facilities and ambulances. Defibrillators are only useful for certain kinds of medical emergencies and paramedics are best qualified to determine when they should and should not be used.

Project Title: Baby Changing Stations/Booths
Project Description: Many families love to take walks throughout Cambridge. Perhaps small baby changing booths would help out the convenience of the walk. They can placed wherever it seems appropriate to have them in Cambridge
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project, because baby changing stations are already available in (men's and women's) restrooms in City Hall and all branches of the Cambridge Public Library.

Project Title: Build a small pier to reach the water
Project Description: Charles River is a huge asset to Cambridge citizens but is still disconnect ed.  Build a waterfront pier where people can actually touch the water and interact with the returning wild life.
Project Status: Not eligible: not City property (the Charles River greenway is state Department of Conservation and Recreation property).

Project Title: To build a bird bath on City Hall property
Project Description: This would provide some more tranquility to a nice place to relax in the city. Also, plant more trees!
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.  100 new trees will be planted as a result of the first PB process.

Project Title: Butterfly Garden
Project Description: This would improve the beauty of Cambridge.  I'm not sure where the best place for the garden would be.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Create a butterfly garden near CRLS
Project Description: So kids could enjoy it and learn about butterflies
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To provide a garden for veterans
Project Description: Gardening is important to veterans' health and can help the recovery process.
Project Status: This project made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: Rooftop Gardens in Central Square
Project Description: rooftop gardens add green space and provide a break from the traffic on the street. They can be a great place to go with kids or with friends or on a date. In these gardens, we could provide public yoga, storytelling for kids, and other fun events.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. The gardens would need to be on a City building to be eligible.

Project Title: Public garden plots on the median strip with benches & S shaped walking path.
Project Description: This idea is to encourage sharing free food and beauty with one's neighbors and anyone visiting the area. There is a neighbor on the street that has a large strawberry patch on her front lawn. So many kids over the years have enjoyed eating her free strawberries each spring. My child has enjoyed eating the cherries off the miniature cherry tree on the strip. There could be four dozen small plots on the strip. A nice curved s path and low fencing could define the spaces. Each spring people could sign up at the library for a plot and then plant what they want. People can pick fruits and vegetables from the plots.  Perhaps there should be a water fountain on the strip near the library so one can rinse and eat! Dog walkers can continue to use the strip as before, having a beautified communal place to walk their dogs. (People here do a good job of picking up after their dogs.) A couple benches and rocking chairs would be nice touches to send a message to enjoy the space.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. Urban fruit trees need proper pruning and maintenance, which would require operating expenses.

Project Title: To build a community garden near a shelter
Project Description: This would provide an area for all of the community to socialize and enjoy the benefits of a community garden.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. Community gardens are hard to site as not all neighbors support them.

Project Title: Expand the Sacramento Street Community Garden into Sacremento Field
Project Description: There are more than 80 families on the waiting list for the Sacramento Street Community Garden.  The adjacent field (Sacramento Field) appears to be underutilized.  Expanding the community garden would satisfy the pent-up demand of the waiting list and would help reinforce the city's interest in promoting urban gardening.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. Community gardens are hard to site as not all neighbors support them.

Project Title: Add Community Gardens to parks!
Project Description: We have great parks with ample lawns and not enough community gardens.  Please add community gardens to parks where there are plenty of spaces!
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. Community gardens are hard to site as not all neighbors support them. A project to add a community garden in Wellington-Harrington made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: Add more community gardens in Cambridge
Project Description: so more residents can participate (there is a long waitlist for community garden plots now).
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. Community gardens are hard to site as not all neighbors support them.  A project to add a community garden in Wellington-Harrington made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: Wellington-Harrington Community Garden
Project Description: The garden would aim to provide resources to grow food while cultivating community partnerships and relationships. A gathering point for cooperative activity, healthy eating, and civic improvement. The garden would provide approximately 20 5'x4' raised plots to interested community members, as well as leisure space, a bike repair stand, fresh water, and other neighborhood resources.
Project Status: This project made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: Cambridge Community Farm
Project Description: Some people need to grow their own food.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Landscaping and beautification of the green area under the BU bridge
Project Description: This is a safety issue as well as an eyesore.  I know there are some goose enthusiasts who oppose any improvement because of the domestic white geese living there.  However, there are plenty of places along the Charles for geese to live -- and these are merely the descendants of somebody's pet geese anyway.
Project Status: Not eligible: not City property.

Project Title: Outdoor ping pong tables
Project Description: Ping-pong is a great "sport" that is fun to play!
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Plant bee-friendly, local, flowering plants in city tree wells
Project Description:
Serves three good purposes:
- Supports local plant populations and helps them thrive despite invasive species
- Beautifies the city
- Helps support local bee populations, combat colony collapse, and improve pollination at community gardens
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.  100 new trees will be planted as a result of the first PB process.

Project Title: To have the city hand out planters to residents for the sidewalks
Project Description: Over a decade ago, the City used to give out planters to residents,  In return, the residents would take care of the planters, like planting flowers, etc.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. The City used to provide planters, but they weren't often well-maintained.

Project Title: More flowers and trees in Cambridge
Project Description: Please add more flowers and trees to beautify the city, especially on streets and near parking lots where there is not a lot of greenery
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.  100 new trees will be planted as a result of the first PB process.

Project Title: Rejuvenate the island on Aberdeen Ave with strips of wild flowers for the birds and bees.
Project Description: Wild flowers would provide habitat for a declining bee population in an urban environment and help the bird population. It might also brighten the commute for some of the many drivers that use the street on a daily bases . My idea would be to go down the center of the island, one rototiller wide, staying 2'-3' away from trees and pols and planting a short wild flower mix. I believe this would be a low budget and no mantenence  proposel; the area to be planted checked by dig safe, the strips rototild and planted, water provided by the existing irrigation system,and mowed over in the fall clean up.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: One Hundred Trees
Project Description: I would like to suggest one hundred trees to be planted for the $600,000 surplus. How beautiful our city could be.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.  100 new trees will be planted as a result of the first PB process.

Project Title: Plant more trees
Project Description: to residential streets with no trees
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.  100 new trees will be planted as a result of the first PB process.

Project Title: More trees citywide
Project Description: never enough!
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.  100 new trees will be planted as a result of the first PB process.

Project Title: Plant trees all along Mass Ave, and in the median
Project Description: The center median is just begging to have trees planted there. If coupled with more trees on the sides of the road, this could be transformed from a concrete eyesore, to a beautiful boulevard the like of the "Commonwealth Avenue Mall" in Boston.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.  100 new trees will be planted as a result of the first PB process.

Project Title: Trees on streets that do not have many including Mass. Avenue.
Project Description: Street trees are beautiful, cooling and air-cleaning.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.  100 new trees will be planted as a result of the first PB process.

Project Title: Replacement of sick trees with the same species of trees citywide
Project Description: We do want to diversify trees, but when a street has all one kind, replace the sick ones with the same kind.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.  100 new trees will be planted as a result of the first PB process.

Project Title: Plant American or Chinese Chestnut trees and fruit trees
Project Description: Chestnut trees once graced Cambridge Streets before a fungus destroyed almost all Chestnut trees in the northeast. New hybrids have been developed to withstand the fungus. It would be nice to see fruit trees planted such as the Roxbury Russet apple, a local variety.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.  100 new trees will be planted as a result of the first PB process.

Project Title: To put trees back in Kendall Sq.
Project Description: Due to construction many trees were removed. There should be more trees to improve the ambiance and provide shade.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.  100 new trees will be planted as a result of the first PB process.

Project Title: A shade tree for the library garden at Collins library
Project Description: Many people enjoy the outdoor space at the library but it is too hot in the afternoon and during the summer to enjoy the garden. During renovation a tree was lost & it would be fitting to replace it with the added benefit of shade.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.  100 new trees will be planted as a result of the first PB process.

Project Title: Adequate watering and care of street trees especially newly planted ones
Project Description: The city plants many new trees and doesn't take enough care of them so a great many die.
Project Status: Not eligible: not a capital project (operating expense.)

Project Title: Purchase a watering truck for city trees
Project Description: Last fiscal year we purchased 100 trees in addition to several hundred already on the planting list. Many of those trees will be in areas with easy access to water. In order to protect our tree asset, we need to ensure they get lots of water when they are most vulnerable.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To provide music studio equipment at youth centers
Project Description: There is not much music equipment available & by providing studio equipment to at least two youth centers on each side of the city. Youth would have another recreational outlet.
Project Status: This project made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: To build a rooftop garden @ the Russell Youth Center
Project Description: This would be a great area for the community to maintain and grow a garden.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project, because the weight of the garden, roof shape, and access to the roof posed feasibility problems.

Project Title: Sound proof music studio and dance studio at Gately
Project Description: This will make our space more creative and foster the artistic advancement of our youth.
Project Status: A project to build music studios at three Youth Centers made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: Create an amphitheater and technology at Gately that would make us the movie center of the city
Project Description: this will bring the city together.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Rooftop Garden at Gately Youth Center
Project Description: it will beautify the city.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project, because the weight of the garden, roof shape, and access to the roof posed feasibility problems.

Project Title: Re-painting interior and exterior of Frisoli Youth Center
Project Description: The center is in need of upgrading.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project, since the center was repainted in the last year and a half.

Project Title: New curtains in the Frisoli Youth Center
Project Description: It covers the windows when we want light in the kitchen.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. A related project to renovate the kitchen at the Frisoli Youth Center made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: To upgrade Frisoli Youth Center w/ new items
Project Description: The Frisoli Center is in need of general upgrading/modernization. Items requested are: New couch, new stereo (microphone/PA system), new foosball table, computers, keyboards, better chairs & window repair.)
Project Status: Two projects involving the Frisoli Youth Center made it to the ballot but did not win funding - one to renovate the kitchen and one to install a music studio and equipment.

Project Title: To provide better fitness equipment in youth centers
Project Description: Much of the equipment in centers are donated & are in need of replacement.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project, because Youth Centers already contain fitness equipment, some of which was updated within the last 2 years.

Project Title: To build more indoor basketball courts & extend hours for youth centers
Project Description: In the winter there is a need for more indoor basketball courts. Also, extended hours for youth would provide greater resources for kids to have things to do.
Project Status: Not eligible. Extending hours for youth centers would require operating funds and building more indoor basketball courts would exceed $600,000.

Project Title: Wading area similar to Frog Pond
Project Description: need more public places to swim and get together. It should be at Cambridge Commons.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To retrofit old buildings for youth centers
Project Description: Instead of letting old buildings to continue to fall into disrepair they should be retrofitted for youth purposes like youth centers or areas for youth sports.
Project Status: Not eligible: creating a new youth center or arena would require operating funds to hire staff to work there.

Project Title: Teen center in North Cambridge, near Fresh Pond mall
Project Description: A positive environment for Cambridge youth (teens) to go have art, sports, etc.  Another center is needed, a safe environment for young teens to go afterschool and on weekends.
Project Status: Not eligible: would require more than $600,000 to build a new youth center.

Project Title: A game center/arcade at Fresh Pond Mall
Project Description: This would be fun for the kids.
Project Status: Not eligible: Fresh Pond Mall is private property.

Project Title: To purchase a summer shuttle for youth
Project Description: Many youth that attend summer programs must provide their own transportation out of pocket. A summer shuttle would allow them to have safe and free travel to various points in the city such as youth centers.
Project Status: Not eligible: would require operating funds to hire drivers and maintain the vehicle.

Project Title: To purchase a shuttle for the high school
Project Description: Students need to be able to get to the high school and there are not a lot of bus routes to the HS. If there could be a shuttle that picks up students on a revolving base close to major T stops it would help students greatly.
Project Status: Not eligible: would require operating funds to hire drivers and maintain the vehicle.

Project Title: A building of playstations and Xboxes and games at Russell Field
Project Description: To give people the gift to come together and socialize with games more often.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To build a sports complex in Cambridge
Project Description: This would provide an area for all residents in Cambridge to come and play a sport that they may enjoy. It would offer indoor leagues etc. & would be a great indoor area for the winter.
Project Status: Not eligible: cost would exceed $600,000.

Project Title: Outdoor Exercise equipment
Project Description: It would be a health benefit to people of all ages. An outdoor gym similar to the ones along the Charles River. It would help make this park even better!
Project Status: A project to install outdoor exercise equipment in Danehy Park and three other parks made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: Outdoor Gyms at Open parks
Project Description: Fitness is crucial for a healthy society and use of open space to provide that salutary benefit to our people will give citizens the option of increasing their health even in the middle of an evening stroll. The exercise equipment could also be sculptures that move to make them an art piece as well.
Project Status: A project to install outdoor exercise equipment in Danehy Park and three other parks made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: Adult circuit training equipment +instructional /health signs at Sennott Park
Project Description: Ideal central location for open access adult fitness circuit. Park is heavily utilized by local neighborhood residents and schools during recess hours. Would add to function and appeal of park across all ages, growing health and community.
Project Status: A project to install outdoor exercise equipment in Danehy Park and three other parks made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: Playground for adults. Like a regular playground, but equipment is bigger/taller/etc.
Project Description: Adults need respite from the monotony of the 9-5 soul-crushing existence. (And keep teenagers off drugs.)
Project Status: Budget Delegates ranked this as a high priority project, but it did not pass final vetting by City staff. There was a City Council order in October 2014 related to the feasibility of creating an adult playground, to which the City responded that we have aimed for creative design that encourages multi- and inter-generational play and that the City has also strategically located elements that bring people of different age groups together, rather than focusing exclusively on one age category.

Project Title: An indoor/outdoor pool for summer and winter
Project Description: Our community is very dull and boring for us and we would like a little for summer and winter
Project Status: Not feasible due to operating costs.

Project Title: Improve/Expand Outdoor Stretching & Exercise Equipment at Danehy Park
Project Description:
Danehy Park is already one of our best parks in Cambridge. We currently have a rudimentary exercise area already designated near the parking lot and between the soccer field and running track (approaching from New Street).
 We suggest improving this area by installing new and additional equipment to facilitate stretching, pull-ups, push-ups, and other body-weight fitness exercises for adults. Major cities in the U.S. have already embraced this idea (Chicago, Los Angeles, Atlanta). 
It would be great to encourage fitness for adults in the community with this improvement!
Project Status: A project to install outdoor exercise equipment in Danehy Park and three other parks made it to the ballot but did not win funding.
Entities: Expand Outdoor Stretching & Exercise Equipment,Danehy Park

Project Title: Parcourse set for exercise & stretching at Sennott Park
Project Description: Sennott is the only large park in Area 4/The Port. Exercise & stretching is needed for all age groups, young to elderly, and for the entire spectrum of abled and physically challenged people. This project would contribute to the health and wellness of the community.
Project Status: A project to install outdoor exercise equipment in Danehy Park and three other parks made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: Outdoor parcourse (challenging fitness trail) located in the portion of Greene Rose Park along Broadway
Project Description: Similar to the parcourse along Charles River at Magazine Beach, this parcourse would challenge people's fitness. There are already benches along the park so participants can be cheered on. Many people jog near Green Rose park and this could be one more stop along the way.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To build a stunt park for parkour
Project Description: This would provide an alternative recreation option for residents of all ages.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To build a rock climbing wall in Danehy Park
Project Description: This would better enhance the park & provide an alternative recreation option.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project and were concerned about liability issues.

Project Title: Enhance "playability" in unusual places (e.g., trampolines in sidewalks, swings at bus stops, etc.)
Project Description: Play has dozens of social, health, and economic benefits.  Scores of other cities have been honored as Playful Cities, but not Cambridge (see http://kaboom.org/playability/playful_city_usa/communities).   That same website provides a good summary about why play matters, and what could be done to increase playability.  This budget fund of $600k could be a terrific start.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Redo basketball hoops & courts
Project Description: Many basketball hoops are in need of repair throughout the city. In locations such as Columbia Park & Area IV specifically.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To have reusable sneakers at all ballcourts
Project Description: people sometimes need better shoes
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Skate park at Dana Park
Project Description: For exercise
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. A skate park is already being built in East Cambridge.

Project Title: Volleyball court at Danehy (or another park)
Project Description: There isn't a public court in the whole city. It could be sand or pavement, with a sturdy net for 3-season usage.  The VB program is pretty big at CRLS, but kids can't use the gym to practice or play pickup since it is reserved for leagues.
Project Status: This project made it to the ballot in but did not win funding.

Project Title: A Learn-to-Bike park
Project Description: It would be great to have a place for kids to learn to bike,  away from busy streets and busy playgrounds.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Skating Rink in the Winter
Project Description: This would create fun recreational activities for the citizens of our community.
Project Status: Not feasible due to operating costs.

Project Title: To build a ice/roller skating rink
Project Description: This would be another fun alternative & popular form of recreation in the city.
Project Status: Not feasible due to operating costs.

Project Title: A lake in Cambridge at Danehy
Project Description: Provide swimming options
Project Status: Not feasible due to unsuitability of site (Danehy was built on a landfill) and cost.

Project Title: Open Air Natural Lap Pool with Open Access
Project Description: A single lane open air lap pool using bio-filtration, similar to this design: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7JoQthEBl6U
Project Status: Not feasible due to operating costs, plus Magazine Beach is DCR property.
Entities: Open Air Natural Lap Pool,Open Access

Project Title: To build more pools
Project Description: There is a need for more pools, especially in West Cambridge. The commute to a pool for some residents is difficult.
Project Status: This project would be too expensive and would require operating funds.

Project Title: Cinder running track around the Fresh Pond reservoir
Project Description: Many people run on the edges of the paved path and need to negotiate tree roots, poison ivy and crumbling asphalt.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To add a net to the top of the tennis wall at the Bergin Park Tennis Courts
Project Description: They recently closed off the fence to create a dog park behind the tennis courts. Yea dogs! But now there is no way to retrieve tennis balls that accidentally go over the wall. Adding a net would prevent  people from having to go on the train tracks to retrieve their lost balls. It is one of the few public courts in Cambridge and CLRS uses  for practice so it gets a lot of use every day.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Create a "Lawn on D" at the bottom of Magazine St and fix the stone bldg there
Project Description: it is a beautification project of a stone bldg. that needs renovation and the addition of a Lawn on D type facility there would also provides Cambridge residents with a new fun outdoor space.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Free Tennis Programs
Project Description: I would like to propose free tennis year-around programs for Youth and Adults. There are quite a number of tennis courts throughout Cambridge that go unused.  Having free tennis programs for youth can introduce them to a new sport at an early age.  Having programs for Adults and Seniors would help them to "keep moving."  There are courts on Harvard Street and Area IV that are ideal for these type of programs for kids.  The additional courts in North Cambridge, etc would give citywide access to tennis programs and make for a healthier city.  The Coordinator and the Instructors would be paid a stipend.  Use of equipment during class would be included in the program.  Courts and sense of Community are FREE!
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.  Tennis programs would be an operating expense.

Project Title: To provide more soccer nets in parks
Project Description: Many parks have areas to play soccer but do not have any soccer nets.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Mini golf on the common!
Project Description: It would be so cool! Mini golf is fun, it's all ages, it's easy to play and easy to score. Someone suggested it be Cambridge-themed, and that's a great idea! Maybe history of Cambridge themed, or famous people of Cambridge themed, etc. Whatever the theme is, having a fun, relaxing game set up in the center of Cambridge would be a great draw for locals, students, visitors, etc. Also, golf is a sport/game that many people don't get to play often, but is actually quite instructive wrt to geometry (trajectory), hand eye coordination, and assessing for and planning strategy (knowing par, how can I achieve it, etc). These are great skills to have, that we rarely have a chance to develop in the normal course of our day.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Portable/modular recreation for all ages:  ping pong tables and mini golf
Project Description: This would support City commitment to recreation for all ages and could be moved to different locations as needed or on a pop-up basis.  Ideally, the mini-golf would be artful and Cambridge-themed, not an out-of-box design but portable/modular games already exist (used on cruise ships and for special events).  Ping pong could be moved to different locations because existing tables are fixed in single locations and hard to access for most City residents.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.  There were questions about project feasibility (who would be responsible for maintenance and security of the items).

Project Title: More swings at Danehy Park (6 more)
Project Description: A lot of people use the swings but there aren't enough.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project since there are already swings in the park.

Project Title: Add one additional picnic table and add three benches with backs for Sennott park
Project Description: The table and benches are usually filled
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Renovate Lopez Street Park (water feature for children needed)
Project Description: It is the only park that I know of that doesn't have a sprinkler for the children to cool off.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Outdoor Fire Pits (aka Artful Gazebo with fire) (aka Winter Oasis)
Project Description:
Cambridge has three problems:
1. Winters are long and hard, and there are minimal public spaces to seek respite
2. The cities public spaces are uninspiring, with minimal art nor even good design taste that has culture relevance or meaning. It makes us feel detached from our space, like robots living for function rather than quality
3. We are heads down much of the time, and need more contexts to build relationships with our neighbors and community.

Everyone want to get warm in the winter, and an outdoor fire pit will bring people together to do just that. If designed artfully, it will make people feel good to look at and be inside of. The literal and figurative warmth will make people feel good, and naturally we will open up to those around us, both in the gazebo and throughout the rest of our day.  The winter oasis for us to recharge, refill, and reconnect with eacthother.
Project Status: Not feasible due to operating costs.

Project Title: Grills, Tables, Picnic Area for Donnelly Field
Project Description: Donnelly Field is a Cambridge treasure.  A few picnic tables and permanent grills could make it an even more inviting place (similar to Danehy). Larger groups could require permits that can help offset maintenance costs.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project for picnic tables. Adding grills requires operating funds for staff to monitoring and maintenance.

Project Title: Grills in the park
Project Description: There are picnic tables in this very popular neighborhood park, but there are no grills. If there were grills, families and groups could grill while playing in the park or on the fields, and watch kickball or softball or baseball.
Project Status: Adding grills requires operating funds for staff to monitoring and maintenance.

Project Title: Public grills in the Cambridge Common
Project Description: Local area residents need a place to BBQ in the summer.
Project Status: Adding grills requires operating funds for staff to monitoring and maintenance.

Project Title: Public Space for community events with circular glow in the dark swings like Lawn on D
Project Description: Create a multi purpose open space that utilizes Danehy Park better. Provide somewhere for people to come and meet and go to events, and improve Danehy Park
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Build a public indoor playground
Project Description: so kids can still play and stay active during the long, cold winter.  It could be anywhere in Cambridge - it does not have to be in this location.
Project Status: Not feasible due to operating costs.

Project Title: Developmentally appropriate playground equipment for children ages 1 - 3 years old
Project Description: Current playground equipment makes it difficult for younger children to play safely among older siblings and friends. Toddlers are in a sensitive stage for movement and gross motor development. Enhancing St. Peter's playground specifically for toddlers would benefit the community at large.
Project Status: Budget Delegates ranked this as a high priority project, but it did not make the final cut for the ballot.

Project Title: Parks for little toddlers
Project Description: Provide a safe place for little ones to play without getting hurt by other activities happening in the same area, especially in Hoyt Field
Project Status: Budget Delegates ranked this as a high priority project, but it did not make the final cut for the ballot.

Project Title: New playground for the Amigos School
Project Description: In 2012, The Amigos School moved to Upton Street and inherited a playground, designed for pre-school aged children, which badly needs updating to be engaging  and suitable for a JK-8 school.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Kayak Storage Structure
Project Description: Kayak Storage Structure for the Community with free kayak rentals for residents.
Project Status: Location is State-owned property and thus not feasible.

Project Title: Add entrance and seating for soccer families
Project Description: The grass fields adjoining the football field are used on weekends by local youth soccer leagues and for pickup games. Add a gate to the grass field will make the area easier to access. Adding some benches around the edge of the field will make the area better place for parents to sit and watch the kids play.
Project Status: Budget delegates did not rank this as a high priority project because seating already exists at the site.

Project Title: To provide more water features in parks for all ages
Project Description: Especially in Columbia Park there is a need and desire for more water features. Sprinklers and various water features are of great enjoyment to all ages.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Lost & Found Boxes at all Parks & Playgrounds
Project Description: Whenever I visit any parks in Cambridge, I always find lost items left behind by previous visitors. My idea is to have a safe, secure, and readily identifiable box in each park where found items can be saved and lost items searched for. If it is not feasible to do this at all parks and playgrounds, then I would propose to do this at the 5 busiest locations throughout the City on a trial basis. Distinctive and practical designs for the Lost & Found boxes could be solicited through a crowd sourced design contest open to residents of all ages.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Gatorade fountains in Danehy Park
Project Description: Joggers need energy when they feel like they will drop
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project (low feasibility).

Project Title: Amphitheater at Danehy Park
Project Description: It would provide a space for educational, cultural, and community events.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project due to the project's cost.  The project made it to the ballot during the first PB cycle but did not win funding.

Project Title: To build an amphitheater in Danehy Park
Project Description: This would provide a place for various cultural events, music & other performances.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project due to the project's cost.  The project made it to the ballot during the first PB cycle but did not win funding.

Project Title: To provide public speakers with an auxiliary jack at parks
Project Description: This would allow music to be played at parks. A curfew on time of use could be used & the maximum volume could be limited.
Project Status: Budget Delegates determined that this project was not feasible since there was no way to prevent theft of the speakers.

Project Title: Create a much-needed park on part of the DPW land
Project Description: This part of Area 3 lacks parks (children have to cross very busy streets to get to one).  And DPW land is very messily kept and under-used, lots of rubble piles. A portion of this land could be restored to be a  playground or some green open space - and it would still allow plenty of space for the DPW.
Project Status: Not feasible due to the proposed location.

Project Title: Consider open space - pocket parks, community gardens wherever there is space
Project Description: needed
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project due to the project's cost and the need for a broader community process needed to implement pocket parks.

Project Title: Restore summer shaded seating at Vellucci Park
Project Description: The summer shaded seating at the Vellucci Memorial Tribute Park in Inman Square has been blocked for 4 years now by the bike rental station. In the hot summer, only seating under the sun is open. Poor placement by people who do not live near this park. Easy and cost-free to fix. Either pushout the bike rental station 2 feet away from the shaded seating (give a 2 foot space between the seating and bike station), or move the bike rental station to the hot sun-drenched side of the park (relocated the bikes from the shaded Hampshire St side to the sun drenched Cambridge St side).
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: I would like to have affordable or free after hours school programs
Project Description: that way moms can go work or go to school
Project Status: Not eligible: hiring staff for these programs is an operating expense.

Project Title: A dog park in East Cambridge
Project Description: We have many dogs, but no fenced recreation place in which to train an exercise them.  It would be a huge benefit to dog owners and non-dog owners alike.
Project Status: Budget Delegates ranked this as a high priority project, but it did not make the final cut for the ballot.  City staff stated that a location-specific community process would be required for any dog park.

Project Title: Fenced area for dog recreation on Lee Street between West St. and Broadway
Project Description: There are  no fenced dog parks in mid-Cambridge.  My service dog needs a chance to run with other dogs off leash.  I can't let him loose without a fence.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Fenced dog park for East Cambridge
Project Description: E. Cambridge has a large dog population but no designated/protected off-leash dog park (save for 3 hours shared use in AM at Gore Park). A small, fenced-in dog run at this currently empty space would provide a safe space for neighborhood dogs to play, which would reduce amount of dogs at playgrounds, school fields, etc.
Project Status: Budget Delegates ranked this as a high priority project, but it did not make the final cut for the ballot.  City staff stated that a location-specific community process would be required for any dog park.

Project Title: Fenced dog park for East Cambridge
Project Description: E. Cambridge has a large dog population but no designated/protected off-leash dog park (save for 3 hours shared use in AM at Gore Park). A small, fenced-in dog run at one end of this large park would provide a safe space for neighborhood dogs to play, which would reduce amount of dogs at playgrounds, school fields, etc.
Project Status: Budget Delegates ranked this as a high priority project, but it did not make the final cut for the ballot.  City staff stated that a location-specific community process would be required for any dog park.

Project Title: Cycle tracks
Project Description: Bike safety. I'm an EMT and think this is a good way to prevent bike accidents.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project because there was not enough information on locations desrired for the proposal.

Project Title: Redesign Danehy Dog Park
Project Description: This dog park is problematic because all the owner seating is in one area which causes all the dogs to crowd around one area. This can cause problems.  Also it would be nice to have synthetic turf made especially for dogs (it exists). I think it needs to be enlarged (there is space). Also it would be fun to have a pool or fountain that dogs can play in on those hot days.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To complete the fencing around Raymond Park
Project Description: Raymond Park has an off leash dog area from 6-9 on most days, which is terrific.  However, the park is only fenced about 90% of the way around and is surrounded by busy roads.  It would be fantastic if the fence around the park could be completed so that the dogs could use the park without any safety concerns.  We don't use the park because of this safety issue.  I can't imagine it wouldn't cost very much.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project, since the park is not meant to be a full-time dog park, which is why the fencing is not closed.

Project Title: Make the Linear Park a real park
Project Description: It's called a park but is just a bike path. Separate dog walkers from bicyclists. Replace the ugly chain link fences. Add benches. Install a small gravel area at both entrances for dogs to use before entering the rest of the park so subsequent peeing won't ruin the grass and bushes.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Completely fenced-in dog parks that allow off-leash dogs
Project Description: There are many dogs in Cambridge, but only 2 fenced-in dog parks where  dogs can legally run off-leash.  There are some more parks that allow dogs off-leash (like Fort Washington Park, but they are not completely enclosed.  Dogs still learning to come when they're called cannot be let off-leash here because there is too much of a risk that they'll leave the park into the street.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. City staff stated that a location-specific community process would be required for any dog park.

Project Title: A Dog Park at Joan Lorentz Park
Project Description: Many residents (including me) enjoy taking their dog for a walk through this beautiful park. It would benefit the community if there was a designated fenced in area for dogs to play and run around freely, because a lot of apartment buildings in this area do not have backyards.
Project Status: The park is already a shared park, to further change this park would require a broader community process outside of PB.

Project Title: Cambridge Community Boat House
Project Description: We should have a community boat house and boat dock.
Project Status: Location is State-owned property and thus not feasible.

Project Title: Boat Dock
Project Description: We should have a boat loading dock.
Project Status: Location is State-owned property and thus not feasible.

Project Title: Have laptops or ipads that we could bring home from school
Project Description: This idea is for all the Cambridge public schools. Some people don't have computers at home when they need it for homework.
Project Status: Proposal was determined difficult to regulate and there were already resources students could utilize to use computers.

Project Title: Provide MacBook Air Laptops for all CPS students who qualify for Free and Reduced Lunch
Project Description: Teaching and learning and being a successful student relies more and more on ACCESS nimble, reliable, mobile access to information and technology.  In order for all CPS students to achieve their potential in school and to compete in the world beyond, it is our responsibility to equip them.  We do this in our schools with some of the greatest teachers and resources available.  Let's truly eliminate the opportunity gap across the economic divides in our city, and provide those who need it most with the tools they require to achieve their potential and beyond.
Project Status: Budget Delegates felt there was a need for the project. But, did not proceed with the proposal due to questions about how the program would be distributed as well as costs associated with the amount of students eligible.

Project Title: To provide more laptops & build a community garden at CCSC
Project Description: CCSC needs more laptops and a community garden would be great for students to be able to garden.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To ensure that all schools still have a computer lab
Project Description: There is still a need for a computer lab in schools and libraries. To have a quiet area for computer use would be beneficial for students and patrons of the library.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project because there was no knowledge of a school that did not have a school lab.

Project Title: After school computer science teachers
Project Description: Give cambridge young adults a way to explore a lucrative and fulfilling potential career path or to learn skills they could incorporate into any modern workplace.  At the same time Cambridge has a thriving tech industry of startups and well established companies that can't find enough talent.  If more local students choose to pursue computer science degrees in college they could serve themselves and their families well and contribute to the cutting edge and knowledge loving spirit of the Cambridge academic and business communities.
Project Status: Not eligible - hiring teachers is an operating expense.

Project Title: To provide more resources for kids with learning disabilities
Project Description: There is a need for more resources when it comes to educating kids with learning disabilities.
Project Status: Budget Delegates were unable to contact idea submitter to understand the proposal identify what kind of resources were needed/wanted. Resources would most likely be operating and not capital expenses.

Project Title: To provide more art supplies for schools
Project Description: There is a need for more art supplies in schools.
Project Status: Budget Delegates were unable to contact idea submitter to understand the proposal and identify specific supplies for specific schools.

Project Title: Digital Arts Education Initiative (DAEI)
Project Description:
What I would like to propose as a PB idea is $100,000 for a comprehensive Digital Arts Education Initiative: 

1. To be implemented in month-long after-school/work and weekend classes specifically for different age groups and at different skill levels.
2. We could move the classes around to various libraries and community centers via portable laptops.
3. The money would be spent to buy computer programs and compensate experts for their time via the Cambridge Public Library.
4. The classes would be free of change but with limited capacity. Ideally no more than 10 at a time.
5. The classes would be filled via a short application process.
6. We could start with specifically music (Ableton) and expand to other Digital Arts programs according to demand.

In doing so we are giving the young creative community tools they can then use as a foundation to become employable in a Digital Arts field. [More description in comments on map]
Project Status: Not eligible due to operating funds required to hold classes.

Project Title: More chairs in all the public schools
Project Description: At the Peabody, Tobin, King, etc.  Many chairs are uncomfortable and they break often.
Project Status: A proposal to purchase new chairs for five public schools made it to the ballot and won funding.

Project Title: Add an auditorium at the Haggerty School
Project Description: The students at the Haggerty School have to squish into the gym for assembly and concerts.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project (low feasibility, high cost).

Project Title: To provide heated bus stations
Project Description: During the winter it would keep patrons who utilize the T warm.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority, because most bus stops in Cambridge are not owned by the City.

Project Title: Make the Windsor St. Side of Fletcher Maynard Academy more welcoming
Project Description: Remove the forbidding iron fence & improve the plantings there so that side looks as nice as the Harvard St, side's playground and City Sprouts garden. Colorful bushes maybe? This trip of land between Harvard & Broadway (excluding the city sprouts part) has never gotten the systematic improvement other parts of the school have received. Lots of students are dropped off/picked up there, and they would probably enjoy better plantings there as much as they enjoy the wonderful playground and city sprouts area.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: To make a bigger stage for Maria Baldwin School
Project Description: So they don't have to clean the stage with gym stuff all over it
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Trying to make schools more safe
Project Description: A lot of people get hurt at the Kennedy Longfellow extension
Project Status: Budget Delegates were unable to contact idea submitter to understand the proposal.

Project Title: To update the Tobin school
Project Description: Vassal Lane/Tobin is in need of general updates & remodeling to make it more modern.
Project Status: Budget Delegates were unable to contact idea submitter to get more specific details.

Project Title: Vending machines at Vassal Lane Upper School
Project Description: Some people are thirsty and some water fountains are broken.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. Project could be addressed outside of the PB process.

Project Title: To have a bigger garden at the Baldwin School so you can grow more stuff
Project Description: Some gardens are really small and are near the play area
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Replace (usually rusted) chain link fences along main streets with wooden fencing
Project Description: One small step to rid the city of eyesores.  We are NOT Somerville, after all.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Buy more snowblowers for the schools
Project Description: Last winter children at most of the elementary schools missed out on recess for more than 2 months due to snow.  Some schools don't have space for indoor recess and children were left without daily physical exercise during the school day.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. They talked to Public Works, who advised that there is enough equipment to clear playgrounds.

Project Title: Better school lunches for public schools, particularly the Rindge Ave. Upper School
Project Description: For a good day at school you have to be energized and ready to learn.  How can you do that when you can't eat?
Project Status: Not eligible: this is not a capital project.

Project Title: Scholarship System For Lower Income Students
Project Description: $600,000 is  a lot of money. There are also plenty of students who live in this city who either drop out of high school, have trouble in high school, or apply to college but have insufficient tuition funds. In order to give some of these students or even one of these students a better opportunity at a good four year college, why not reward them and guide them through a college scholarship program, specifically for Newtowne Court/Washington Elms/Columbia Terrace students where a lot of current violence has occurred. Give students an opportunity. Show them how to pursue it and may be others will follow suit.
Project Status: Not eligible: this is not a capital project.

Project Title: Give money to charter schools
Project Description: Public schools get way more funds and help from the government
Project Status: Not eligible: this is not a capital project.

Project Title: Financial Health Youth Local Bank Accounts
Project Description: Help build the financial literacy abilities and wealth building skills of our youth by remunerating their participation in community activities (ie. helping the elderly, cleaning up a public space, taking younger siblings to the library to name a few) by opening first time youth accounts in local banks. Invite local banks and individuals to match Cambridge Participatory Budgeting Funds granted.
Project Status: Not eligible: this is not a capital project.

Project Title: Cadet Platform Pilot
Project Description: Systemic inequality within our schools results in a loss of potential among those in communities with the most work to be done. Providing students with intrinsic motivators to allow them to grow would not only allow them to separate their school work from a prescribed daily routine, but also extend what they are learning to a long term vision for what they could be as adults. This would be a great way to test the ways we could build a more inclusive, open, progressive, and effective education system. The full description of the platform can be found here: igg.me/at/cadet
Project Status: Not eligible: this is not a capital project.

Project Title: Heat lamps at high traffic bus stops
Project Description: Winter is terrible in Cambridge, especially this past year. Many people wait for the bus in high traffic bus stops such as the Mass Ave. stop in Central Square. Why not make it a little more managable by providing heat lamps under existing structures at bus stops in high traffic areas during rush hour.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority, because most bus stops in Cambridge are not owned by the City.

Project Title: Increase the number of glass enclosures with benches at bus stops
Project Description: With the move to increase the use of public transportation and knowing the variety of weather in NE, having attractive enclosures that allow riders to sit if necessary and step out of the inclement weather is important.    To often elderly have no place to sit, and I witness many standing exposed to the elements.   Thank you.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority, because most bus stops in Cambridge are not owned by the City.

Project Title: Yellow Bumpers at Bus Stops Citywide
Project Description: Helps blind people know where bus stops are, and where they can stand safely.
Project Status: Budget Delegates determined this was not a high priority project because of the numerous bus stops in Cambridge and the high cost of the project.

Project Title: To have monitors at bus stops to see when the next bus is coming
Project Description: at bus stops around Cambridge. If you don't know when the bus is coming, you might miss it.
Project Status: A proposal to add real-time bus arrival monitors in Harvard Square made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: New bus stop at the Russell Youth Center
Project Description: If people have trouble walking we can have closer bus stops
Project Status: Budget Delegates determined this was not a high priority project because the exisiting bus stops were within walking distance to the youth center, plus bus routes are managed by the MBTA.

Project Title: Build a new, non-commercial, Bus Shelter on Rindge Ave. opp Comeau Field at the #83 Bus turnaround
Project Description: The current shelter is broken down. Missing glass. Ugly. Inadequate shelter. Weird "bench" not suitable for waiting passengers, etc...
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. Bus shelters improvements are part of the City's existing capital plan.

Project Title: Clearer bus stop signs so cars don't block bus stops
Project Description: Bus stop signs that indicate no standing, no stopping, $100 fine on Broadway.
Project Status: Not eligible: this is not a capital project.

Project Title: To have more bus shelters
Project Description: During the winter & various elements there needs to be more bus shelters.
Project Status: Bus shelters already exist at Churchill Avenue. The proposal was not specific on other city locations that need shelters so it was not a high priority project for Budget Delegates.

Project Title: To build real time bus arrival monitors
Project Description: This would allows commuters to know when buses would be arriving & help the commute throughout the city.
Project Status: A proposal to add real-time bus arrival monitors in Harvard Square made it to the ballot but did not win funding.

Project Title: Add a bus shelter on Alpine Street
Project Description: for people waiting for the 74, 75, and 78 buses.
Project Status: Proposal was deemed not feasible, due to no space on the sidewalk to add a bus shelter.

Project Title: Add more bus shelters to Prospect Street
Project Description: to create shade from the sun/shelter from the rain for people who are waiting for the bus.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project. Bus shelters improvements are part of the City's existing capital plan.

Project Title: Improved Bus Stop / Bicycle Lane Pavement Markings
Project Description:
Central Square is heavily used by all modes of transportation - transit vehicles, pedestrians, bicyclists, and motor vehicles. To call attention to the presence of all modes, I propose a refresh of all the pavement markings in the Square with the following improvements:

- Green pavements have been used to great success in other parts of the city and the region to call attention to the presence of bicycle lanes. The green pavement should be used along the length of the corridor to let all users know they should stay alert when parking, making turning movements, exiting their vehicle, or crossing the street. Likewise, the bicycle lanes should have pavement markings alerting bicyclists to the need to yield to pedestrians in crosswalks.

- Red pavements can be used to mark bus stops to alert motorists to not park or idle in stops, creating a clearly defined zone; also alerts bicyclists to the potential for a bus to pull in/out.
Project Status: A proposal to paint bike lanes green in Central and Inman Squares made it to the ballot and won funding.

Project Title: To have bus only lanes
Project Description: To reduce traffic congestion (Inman Square; Porter to Kendall Square)
Project Status: It was deemed not feasible to remove car lanes in favor of only bus lanes. Would require significant re-routing of traffic.

Project Title: More bike paths on Mass Ave
Project Description: this will make the city healthier, safer, and more fun.
Project Status: A version of this proposal made it to the ballot.

Project Title: Painted Green Bike Lanes everywhere in Cambridge
Project Description: Green-painted bike lanes stand-out visually AND mentally! Drivers easily see them, and the green lanes in turn cue drivers and heighten awareness of bike riders. Everyone benefits -- the possibility of bikers becomes more front of mind for driver, fewer car doors will be opened and injure bikers, fewer drivers will turn a corner unaware of bikers.
Project Status: A proposal to paint bike lanes green in Central and Inman Squares made it to the ballot and won funding.

Project Title: Add bike lane allowing people to get from Main Street to 3rd Street
Project Description: There was no good way and will still be no good way after the Main Street project to bike from Main to 3rd Street.  A 100-foot contraflow bike lane at the corner of the Microsoft Building would solve that!
Project Status: Proposal is under construction.

Project Title: Revamping bike lanes
Project Description:
With all the students in Cambridge, and so many of them on bikes, plus other people too, I think we could really improve the safety and road conditions for bikes in Cambridge. I hold my breath every time I bike up Beacon Street at night!

The bike path along the Charles is also hard to maneuver at night between the BU bridge and River Street. And I avoid Mass Ave on my bike because of the scary buses. Many cities have great safe bike lanes, I think Cambridge has the brain power and can do much better!
Project Status: A proposal to paint bike lanes green in Central and Inman Squares made it to the ballot and won funding.

Project Title: Extend bike lane on Mass Ave from Bigelow to Trowbridge St
Project Description: While most of Mass Ave has a bike lane, this short stretch does not. If there's not enough space for a lane on the street, more prominent sharrows or road signs would be helpful to alert people who are driving so that they see people who are biking.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Safer bike travel up Peabody St to Mass Ave
Project Description: It's difficult to travel this way on a bike safely and legally. Cars are traveling very quickly on both sides as you approach the split in the road - it's scary and unsafe, and also inconvenient to people in cars to have people on bikes mixed in. One solution might be to place a bike light in addition to the traffic light  to allow bikes to get out in front of cars by several seconds and bear left towards Mass Ave, if it is possible to incorporate that with other traffic signals in the area.  It would be great to hear if people have other ideas.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project because it would require significant design coordination & cost considerations that are better suited outside the PB process.

Project Title: Legal bike route from Mid-Cambridge to Putnam Ave or Paul Dudley
Project Description: Right now, it is extremely difficult to get from Mid-Cambridge to the BU bridge, which is a good route for many bicycle commuters who work on the Boston side of the river. As it stands, the fastest legal route to get from the Cambridge Public Library to the BU bridge is to go through Central,  and then down Magazine or Western. It would be much easier to access either Putnam or the Dudley Bike Path if there were counterflow bike lanes installed somewhere around the intersection between Mass Ave, Putnam and Trowbridge.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project because it would require significant design coordination & cost considerations that are better suited outside the PB process.

Project Title: Better biking lanes
Project Description: The streets with bike lanes that are honored work well. But there are too few. Can't we designate some streets as "bike preferred" routes and put real bike lanes in them and promote them?
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project because there was not enough information on locations desired for the proposal.

Project Title: More bike lanes that are higher up like the bike lanes near MIT
Project Description: When there are no bike lanes on the roads, people tend to start biking on the sidewalks and that can cause an accident when a lot of people are walking or have to share the road with bikes which can cause accidents as well.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project because there was not enough information on locations desrired for the proposal.

Project Title: Paint the bike lanes green & paint more bike lanes
Project Description: safety.
Project Status: A version of this proposal made it to the ballot.

Project Title: Extend the bike path from Alewife to Watertown via Fresh Pond
Project Description: Extend the bikepath from alewife to Watertown via Fresh Pond
Project Status: Not eligible: DCR jurisdiction.

Project Title: Bike lanes on the bridge between Alewife and Fresh Pond Circle
Project Description: The bridge sees frequent foot traffic and a good number of bikes that ride on the sidewalk, often at high speeds. This is a danger both to pedestrians as well as the people on bikes. A dedicated bike lane could fix this.
Project Status: Not eligible: DCR jurisdiction.

Project Title: Cycle track on River Street
Project Description: Traffic goes by so quickly on River Street, and the bike lane is narrow. River Street has lots of potholes where water pools and not only does this splash bikers, it also splashes pedestrians.
Project Status: Proposal is part of 5 year city plan.

Project Title: Cycle Tracks On Broadway/ Mass Ave
Project Description: Cyclists make our city better.  They reduced pollution and keep our citizens in good health.  Cycling, however, is increasingly dangerous, mostly because cars/ buses and bikes share the same niche.  Recently, local cyclists have suffered maiming accidents and death through no fault of their own.  Cycle tracks (like those on Vassar St by MIT) separate cyclists, pedestrians, and cars to make safe commutes possible for all.  Additionally, R-hand turn lanes for cyclists would eliminate some very dangerous merges.
Project Status: Proposal is part of Bicycle Network plan.

Project Title: Finish the bridge by Harvard Square
Project Description: it would reduce traffic.
Project Status: Not eligible through the PB process, Mass DOT jurisdiction.

Project Title: Make the Cambridge St/O'Brien Highway intersection safe for bikes
Project Description: People always bike on the sidewalk here because there are no bike lanes and the intersection is really dangerous with cars coming over the bridge driving fast. It would be great to figure out a way to make this intersection safe for bikers to ride in the street and leave the sidewalks for pedestrians.
Project Status: Proposal is under design..

Project Title: Invest in trial deployments of separated cycle lanes with removable bollards/strike posts.
Project Description: This would address the urgent need for safer cycling in Cambridge. The approach of trialling low cost removable improvements has been successful in NYC and elsewhere.  Complete streets approaches like that implemented on Western Ave are very pretty but cost an absolute fortune per mile of improved cycling infrastructure. We can't afford to implement these kind of treatments everywhere they are needed. This idea would bring a new, affordable approach while giving potential NIMBY's comfort that if the treatments don't work they can be easily reversed.
Project Status: Budget Delegates did not rank this as a high priority project.

Project Title: Build a bike path to connect the Minuteman path to the Charles River bike path
